title: Shadwell v. Craigie
description: Teresa Shadwell appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Respondents in this medical malpractice action. Shadwell alleged that her treating physician was negligent in (1) failing to discuss lab results with her, and (2) failing to report those lab results to her referring physician. The trial court dismissed both claims as being barred by the three-year statute of limitations. We concluded Shadwellâ€™s first cause of action is barred by the statute of repose. However, her second cause of action is a novel issue in South Carolina and requires further factual development. Therefore, the trial court improperly granted summary judgment as to that issue.

12211


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Teresa Shadwell, Appellant,
v.
James Craigie, M.D., Individually and as agent for Loris 
        Surgical Associates and Loris Surgical Associates, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge



Opinion No. 3883
Heard June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed November 
  1, 2004




  AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED
  
   


  
    
      
Ralph J. Wilson, of Conway, for Appellant.
William W. Doar, Jr., of Georgetown, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Teresa Shadwell appeals 
  the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of James Craigie, M.D., 
  and Loris Surgical Associates (collectively â€œRespondentsâ€) in this medical malpractice 
  action.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part and remand.
FACTS  
In January 1996, Shadwell was referred to Dr. Craigie 
  by her treating physician, Dr. Robert A. Ziff, because she was experiencing 
  lower abdominal pain.Â  Dr. Craigie ordered laboratory tests for Shadwell at 
  Loris Hospital Laboratory prior to performing a colonoscopy.Â  The lab results 
  were reported to Dr. Craigie on January 25, 1996.Â  The results showed Shadwell 
  had an elevated creatinine level, indicating problems with her kidneys.Â  Dr. 
  Craigie performed a colonoscopy on Shadwell on January 26, 1996.Â  Shadwell returned 
  to Dr. Craigieâ€™s office for a follow-up examination on February 9, 1996, at 
  which time she complained of abdominal cramps and diarrhea.Â  Shadwell was scheduled 
  to return on March 27, 1996, on a â€œneeds basis â€“ only if she continued to have 
  complaints,â€ but she did not appear for the appointment.Â  Dr. Craigie had no 
  further contact with Shadwell following the February visit.Â  Dr. Craigie never 
  informed Shadwell of the test results indicating problems with her kidneys, 
  nor did he forward the results to Shadwellâ€™s treating physician, Dr. Ziff.Â  
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In January and February of 1998, while pregnant 
  with her daughter, Shadwell underwent two twenty-four hour kidney tests at Loris 
  Hospital at the direction of Dr. Ziff.Â  These tests revealed her kidneys were 
  functioning at only twenty percent of normal capacity.Â  Following the birth 
  of her daughter, Shadwellâ€™s kidney function began to deteriorate, at one point 
  functioning at only eight percent.Â  Because her kidneys were not functioning 
  properly, Shadwell went on dialysis to assist in removing toxins from her blood.Â  
  On August 14, 2000, Shadwell successfully underwent a kidney transplant. 
In 2001, Shadwell filed suit against Dr. Ziff and 
  other physicians who provided treatment during her pregnancy.Â  One of the grounds 
  for the lawsuit was that Dr. Ziff failed to properly diagnose her condition 
  after receiving the results from the 1998 kidney function tests.Â Â Â  
During the course of preparing for the case against 
  Dr. Ziff, the parties took several depositions including that of Shadwell, Dr. 
  Ziff, and Dr. Craigie.Â  It is not clear from the record when Shadwell learned 
  of the January 1996 lab results showing elevated creatinine levels.Â  During 
  Dr. Craigieâ€™s August 17, 2001 deposition, he confirmed the January 1996 lab 
  results.Â  During Shadwellâ€™s September 12, 2001 deposition, she testified that 
  she learned at Duke Hospital in late 1998 that she should have been made aware 
  of prior lab results.Â  It is not altogether clear whether she was referring 
  to the results from Dr. Craigieâ€™s 1996 lab tests or from the tests performed 
  early in 1998 during her pregnancy.Â  During Dr. Ziffâ€™s October 17, 2001 deposition, 
  he was shown the results from the January 1996 tests for the first time.Â Â Â Â  

Shadwell commenced the current action against Dr. 
  Craigie and Loris Surgical Associates on March 4, 2002, alleging, among other 
  things, that Dr. Craigie was negligent in: (1) failing to discuss these lab 
  results with her, and (2) failing to forward a copy of the results to Dr. Ziff, 
  as her referring physician, or to inform any of Shadwellâ€™s other physicians 
  of the abnormal results.Â  Shadwell alleged in her complaint that she first became 
  aware of Dr. Craigieâ€™s negligence when she received discovery in the prior case.Â  
  Specifically, she stated â€œ[t]hat until August 17, 2001, [she] was unaware that 
  any duty had been breached by [Dr.] Craigie or that any negligence occurred.â€ 


Respondents answered the complaint with general 
  denials and asserted that the statute of limitations governing medical malpractice 
  actions barred the case.Â  Accordingly, Respondents moved to have the case dismissed 
  under Rule 12(c), SCRCP.Â  On July 8, 2002, the court denied the motion finding 
  it to be premature.Â  Respondents then filed a motion for reconsideration.Â  The 
  primary dispute at the hearing on the motion for reconsideration concentrated 
  on whether the action was filed within the six-year time period established 
  by the statute of repose. 
On September 23, 2002, the trial court issued an 
  order denying the motion for reconsideration holding that a genuine issue of 
  material fact existed concerning when the physician-patient relationship ended 
  between Shadwell and Dr. Craigie.Â  Thus, the trial court found that an issue 
  of fact existed as to whether Shadwellâ€™s action was barred by the statue of 
  repose. Â Following receipt of this order, Respondents moved pursuant 
  to Rule 59(e), SCRCP to alter or amend, seeking a ruling as to whether the three-year 
  statute of limitations also acted as a time bar to Shadwellâ€™s action.
In an order dated November 15, 2002, the trial 
  court granted Respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment.Â  Based on the deposition 
  testimony taken in Shadwellâ€™s prior lawsuit, the court ruled that by the end 
  of 1998, Shadwell â€œwas aware of sufficient facts that would have put her on 
  notice of the existence of a cause of action against Dr. Craigie for allegedly 
  not informing her of the results of the lab tests performed on her on January 
  24, 1996.â€Â  Therefore, because Shadwell did not file her suit against Dr. Craigie 
  until March 2002, her action was barred by the three-year statute of limitations.
Shadwell filed a motion to alter or amend arguing 
  the trial court erred in dismissing her claims.Â  Shadwell argued that she raised 
  two claims in her complaint: (1) that Dr. Craigie committed malpractice in failing 
  to inform her of the lab results; and (2) that Dr. Craigie committed malpractice 
  in failing to inform her referring physician of the lab results.Â  Because she 
  did not learn until Dr. Ziffâ€™s October 17, 2001 deposition that Dr. Craigie 
  failed to inform him of the test results, Shadwell argued the trial court erred 
  in also dismissing her second claim as barred by the statute of limitations.Â  
  Shadwell argued that these two allegations of negligence constituted separate 
  and independent causes of action, and thus, the court erred in dismissing her 
  case.Â  The trial court denied Shadwellâ€™s motion by order dated November 25, 
  2002.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, 
  this Court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 
  56(c), SCRCP.â€Â  Fisher v. Stevens, 355 S.C. 290, 294, 584 S.E.2d 149, 
  151 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Accordingly, summary judgment is appropriate when â€œâ€˜there 
  is no genuine issue as to any material fact and . . . the moving party is entitled 
  to a judgment as a matter of law.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Rule 56(c), SCRCP).Â  
  â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, as will preclude summary 
  judgment, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom 
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  McNair 
  v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 341, 499 S.E.2d 488, 493 (Ct. App. 1998).
LAW/ANALYSIS  

I

Shadwell argues the trial court erred 
  in granting summary judgment because the record does not support the trial courtâ€™s 
  finding that she should have known about Dr. Craigieâ€™s failures by late 1998.Â  
  Regardless of when Shadwell learned of Dr. Craigieâ€™s failures, the record in 
  this case supports a finding that Shadwellâ€™s cause of action for failure to 
  inform her of the test results was barred by the statute of repose. 
  [1] 
Medical malpractice actions are governed by a three-year 
  statute of limitations and a six-year statute of repose.Â  The statute provides:

In any action, other than 
  actions controlled by section (B), to recover damages for injury to the person 
  arising out of any medical, surgical, or dental treatment, omission, or operation 
  by any licensed health care provider . . . acting within the scope of his profession 
  must be commenced within three years from the date of the treatment, omission, 
  or operation giving rise to the cause of action or three years from date of 
  discovery or when it reasonably ought to have been discovered, not to exceed 
  six years from date of occurrence, or as tolled by this section.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-545(A) 
  (Supp. 2003) (emphasis added). [2] 
Respondents contended the trial court properly granted summary 
  judgment in their favor because the occurrence took place more than six years 
  prior to the commencement of Shadwellâ€™s action. On the other hand, Shadwell 
  argued that the statute of repose did not bar her action against Dr. Craigie 
  because the time period was tolled while she was under Dr. Craigieâ€™s continuous 
  treatment.Â  Thus, Shadwell asserted the â€œoccurrenceâ€ did not happen until after 
  she missed her March 27, 1996 appointment.Â  
Our supreme court has recently addressed the continuous 
  treatment doctrine.Â  In Harrison v. Bevilacqua, 354 S.C. 129, 580 S.E.2d 
  109 (2003), the guardian for James L. McLean sued the Department of Mental Health 
  and various physicians for negligence in their treatment of McLean from 1982 
  until his discharge in 1995.Â  The court declined to adopt the continuous treatment/continuous 
  tort doctrine, stating that â€œjudicial adoption of the continuous treatment rule 
  would run afoul of the absolute limitations policy the Legislature has clearly 
  setâ€ through statute, including the statute of repose.Â  Harrison, 354 
  S.C. at 138, 580 S.E.2d at 114; see also Hoffman v. Powell, 
  298 S.C. 338, 339-340, 380 S.E.2d 821, 821 (1989) (holding that the statute 
  of repose â€œconstitutes an outer limit beyond which a medical malpractice claim 
  is barred, regardless of whether it has or should have been discovered.â€); Dunbar 
  v. Carlson, 341 S.C. 261, 269, 533 S.E.2d 913, 917 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œ[T]he 
  statute of repose imposes an outer limit for filing a medical malpractice action, 
  regardless of when it is discovered.â€).Â  Thus, the statute of repose in the 
  present case was not tolled by the time period between Shadwellâ€™s February 1996 
  and March 1996 appointments, presumably a period of time she was under the care 
  of Dr. Craigie.Â  
We need only determine the time of the â€œoccurrenceâ€ 
  in order to determine if the statute of repose barred this cause of action.Â  
  This court has previously determined the date of occurrence in a medical malpractice 
  claim.Â  Oâ€™Tuel v. Villani, 318 S.C. 24, 455 S.E.2d 698 (Ct. App. 1995), 
  overruled on other grounds by Iâ€™on, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 
  338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000).Â  In Oâ€™Tuel, parents alleged their 
  child was injured during birth when they discovered he had certain physical 
  and learning disabilities when he entered school.Â  They sued the delivering 
  physician nine years after the child was born.Â  This court found that since 
  the date of â€œoccurrenceâ€ was the date of the childâ€™s delivery, the statute of 
  repose barred the parentsâ€™ action against the physician.Â  Oâ€™Tuel, 318 
  S.C. at 27, 455 S.E.2d at 700 (holding that â€œwhile the parentsâ€™ claim may have 
  accrued when Adam started school, their claim is nonetheless barred because 
  it was instituted more than six years from the date of occurrence, in this case, 
  the date of Adamâ€™s birthâ€).
  In the present case, the occurrence happened when Dr. Craigie 
  failed to inform Shadwell about the elevated creatinine levels discovered in 
  her January 1996 test results.Â  Dr. Craigie knew about the results before the 
  January 26, 1996 colonoscopy.Â  Dr. Craigie should have informed Shadwell within 
  a reasonable time after learning the results, either at the time of the colonoscopy, 
  or at the latest, at her follow-up appointment on February 9, 1996.Â  Since he 
  failed to do so, we agree with the trial court that the occurrence in this case 
  is no later than the date of Shadwellâ€™s last appointment, February 9, 1996.Â  
  Accordingly, the six-year statute of repose for Shadwellâ€™s cause of action against 
  Dr. Craigie for his failure to inform her of the test results expired prior 
  to the March 4, 2002 filing of the action against Dr. Craigie, regardless of 
  when Shadwell discovered his omission. 
II
Shadwell also argues the trial court erred in not 
  specifically addressing her â€œsecond cause of actionâ€ of Dr. Craigieâ€™s failure 
  to inform Dr. Ziff, her treating physician, of the 1996 test results. Â 
As noted, among other allegations, Shadwell averred 
  in her complaint that Dr. Craigie committed two acts of negligence: (1) failing 
  to inform her of the test results, and (2) failing to forward a copy of the 
  results to Dr. Ziff as her referring physician. On appeal, Shadwell argues her 
  second allegation of negligence constitutes a separate cause of action.Â  She, 
  therefore, argues the evidence shows she could not have been aware that Dr. 
  Craigie failed to inform Dr. Ziff of the test results until Dr. Ziff testified 
  to as much in his deposition on October 17, 2001.Â  Accordingly, since she filed 
  her complaint in March 2002, the statute of limitations would not act as a bar 
  to this cause of action. [3] 
To support her contention that Dr. Craigieâ€™s failure 
  to inform her treating physician of the test results constitutes a separate 
  cause of action, Shadwell relies on this courtâ€™s decision in Jernigan v. 
  King, 312 S.C. 331, 440 S.E.2d 379 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  In Jernigan, 
  a physician admitted the plaintiff to a hospital after plaintiff complained 
  of severe headaches.Â  Id. at 332, 440 S.E.2d at 380.Â  While covering 
  for plaintiffsâ€™ admitting physician, another doctor was called to answer an 
  emergency code from plaintiffâ€™s room.Â  After resuscitating plaintiff, this physician 
  ordered a number of tests be performed including a CT scan.Â  Thereafter, the 
  admitting physician resumed care for plaintiff.Â  Id.
Neither physician reviewed the results of the CT 
  scan, which revealed plaintiff was suffering from intracranial hemorrhaging.Â  
  Id.Â  Four days later, while again covering for plaintiffâ€™s admitting 
  physician, the same doctor who ordered the first CT scan ordered a second.Â  
  Upon receiving and reviewing the results, the doctor performed immediate surgery 
  to remedy the problem.Â  Id. at 332-33, 440 S.E.2d at 380.Â  Thus, the 
  essence of plaintiffâ€™s claim was that the delay in treatment caused permanent 
  brain damage.Â  Id. at 333, 440 S.E.2d at 380. 
Specifically, the plaintiff averred that once the 
  physician ordered the CT scan the first time, he had an obligation to review 
  the results, or at the very least, to see that another physician did.Â  Id.Â  
  Although this Court eventually found against the plaintiff, in reaching this 
  conclusion, we stated:Â  â€œ[w]e assume, without deciding, [plaintiff] is 
  correct that once [the operating physician] ordered a CT scan on August 3, he 
  was under a duty to see to it that the scan was performed and to see the results, 
  or to see to it that someone else evaluated the results.â€Â  Id. at 333, 
  440 S.E.2d at 381 (emphasis added).Â  
From this statement, Shadwell asserts we recognized 
  a separate and distinct cause of action for a physicianâ€™s failure to inform 
  a patientâ€™s primary physician of pertinent test results. Shadwell, however, 
  fails to recognize that in Jernigan we specifically declined to rule 
  on the issue. Â Accordingly, as a review of our case law uncovers a lack of authority 
  on point, the question is a matter of first impression. 
  [4]   
Â Here, the trial court summarily disposed of this 
  issue, which could have significant implications concerning the liability to 
  which consulting physicians may be exposed. Additionally, application of the 
  statute of limitations and/or the statute of repose to any cause of action Shadwell 
  may have for Dr. Craigieâ€™s failure to report the test results to Dr. Ziff may 
  differ from her other cause of action. Moreover, the standard for reporting 
  such findings and proximate cause are issues that need to be developed further. 
  We, thus, hold the trial court improperly disposed of the question by granting 
  summary judgment. ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 
  320 S.C. 143, 153, 463 S.E.2d 618, 624 (Ct. App.1995) (stating that although 
  all issues of novel impression do not require a trial, summary judgment is inappropriate 
  where further inquiry into the facts is desirable to clarify application of 
  the law); See Shea v. State Dept. of Mental Retardation, 279 S.C. 
  604, 611, 310 S.E.2d 819, 822 (Ct. App. 1983) (â€œIf the statuteâ€™s application 
  is not absolutely clear as a matter of law, [the] question should not be decided 
  without fully developing the facts by means of trial.â€) overruled on other 
  grounds by McCall v. Batson, 285 S.C. 243, 329 S.E.2d 741 (1985). [5] 
CONCLUSION 
Shadwellâ€™s cause of action based on the failure of Dr. Craigie to inform her 
  of the test results is barred by the statute of repose.Â  Because the issue of 
  whether the respondents are liable to Shadwell for Dr. Craigieâ€™s failure to 
  notify Dr. Ziff of the test results needs further factual development and is 
  a novel issue, we hold the trial court erred in granting summary judgment. Â Accordingly, 
  the trial courtâ€™s order is reversed as to the latter issue, and this case is 
  remanded to the trial court for a determination as to whether Dr. Craigieâ€™s 
  failure to notify Dr. Ziff of the abnormal test results constituted actionable 
  negligence for which Shadwell may recover against the Respondents.Â Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED. 
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   [1] Â  An appellate court may affirm 
    a trial courtâ€™s order based on any grounds found in the record.Â  Rule 220(c), 
    SCACR; Iâ€™on, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 
    S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (holding that an appellate court may affirm the circuit 
    courtâ€™s ruling using any additional reasons that are both raised by the respondentâ€™s 
    brief and found within the record). Respondents also argue this basis for 
    affirmance in their brief.

 
   
    [2] Â  In Langley v. Pierce, 313 S.C. 401, 438 S.E.2d 242 (1993), 
    our supreme court discussed the tolling language in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-545(A).Â  
    The court noted that the tolling language in subsection (A) â€œclearly indicates 
    that the only tolling of Â§ 15-3-545(A) intended by the legislature 
    is that contained in subsection (D).â€Â  Langley, 313 S.C. at 403, 438 
    S.E.2d at 243.Â  Subsection (D) provides that the statute will be tolled to 
    a certain extent for minors injured by healthcare providers.Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
    Â§ 15-3-545(D) (Supp. 2003). 

 
   
    [3]  Although Respondents suggest this argument is not preserved because 
    Shadwell did not raise it at the time the motion for summary judgment was 
    heard, we disagree.Â  Both allegations of negligence were included in Shadwellâ€™s 
    complaint. Furthermore, Shadwellâ€™s position at the summary judgment hearing 
    was to argue against Respondentsâ€™ assertion that her action was time barred, 
    not to support her allegations of negligence.Â  Finally, Shadwell did specifically 
    raise this claim in her Rule 59(e) motion submitted after receipt of the courtâ€™s 
    summary judgment order. Moreover, in denying Shadwellâ€™s motion for reconsideration, 
    the court found: â€œthat both parties fully expounded all issues raised in [Shadwellâ€™s] 
    Motion for Reconsideration at the previous hearing.â€ Â We therefore 
    find the issue is preserved for our review.Â  See Staubes v. City 
    of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 529 S.E.2d 543 (2000).Â Â Â  

 
   
    [4]  In fact, Respondents argue in their brief that it is a novel issue.

 
   
    [5]  While Jernigan did not recognize a separate cause of action 
    for failure of a consulting physician to notify the referring physician of 
    a patientâ€™s abnormal test results, we suggest there is a duty on the part 
    of the consulted physician to report abnormal test results to the treating 
    physician if the results indicate a need for further follow-up or treatment. 
    Other courts have likewise concluded such a duty exists. See Sinclair 
    v. Roth, 811 A.2d 460, 465 (2002) (â€œThere is little doubt that the specialist 
    has a duty to advise the referring physician of his findings.â€); Munoz 
    v. South Miami Hospital, Inc., 764 So. 2d 854, 856 (Fla.Â  Dist. Ct. App. 
    2000) (â€œ[M]edical professionals must, under some circumstances, see to it 
    that serious conditions which they know about [are] remedied either by themselves 
    or by someone else competent to do so.â€); Santos v. Kim, 706 N.E.2d 
    658, 663 (Mass. 1999) (finding that the director of a laboratory had a duty 
    to report laboratory test results to plaintiffâ€™s treating physician).

title: Windsor Green Owners Association, Inc. v. Allied Signal, Inc.
description: Allied Signal, Inc. appeals from an order of the circuit court granting summary judgment to Windsor Green Owners Association, Inc. on its claim for breach of contract.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Windsor Green Owners Association, Inc., Respondent,
v.
      Allied Signal, Inc., Honeywell International, Inc., and Stanley V. Kaminski, 
        Defendants,
      of whom Allied Signal, Inc. and Honeywell International, Inc. are,
      Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
John L. Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3884
Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed November 1, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        William S. Brown and Jeffrey W. Newman, both of Greenville, for Appellants.
        E. Glenn Elliott, Robert E. Lee, and Samuel F. Arthur, III, all of 
          Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment to Windsor 
  Green Owners Association, Inc. on its claim that Allied Signal, Inc. was contractually 
  liable for damages to the common area of a condominium complex that were caused 
  by a fire.Â  The court found Windsor Green was a third-party beneficiary to a 
  lease agreement Allied had with one of the condominium owners.Â  Allied appeals.Â  
  We reverse.
FACTS
On November 23, 1998, Allied entered into a rental agreement with J.B. Allen 
  Real Estate for the lease of a condominium at the Windsor Green condominium 
  complex in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.Â  J.B. Allen Real Estate was the agent 
  for the owners, Earl and Ula Reitzel.Â  Windsor Green, the homeownersâ€™ association 
  for the complex, was not mentioned in the rental agreement.Â  
Allied allowed one of its employees, Stanley Kaminski, to move into the condominium 
  following a fire that destroyed his home.Â  On November 28, 1998, the condominium 
  caught fire.Â  An investigation revealed that Kaminskiâ€™s son, Michael, had set 
  both fires.Â  Michael confessed to a history of arsonist activity.Â  Allied had 
  no knowledge of Michaelâ€™s arsonist tendencies prior to the condominium fire.Â  

Windsor Green is comprised of all the individual condominium owners.Â  Each 
  owner retains an undivided interest in the common areas of the complex.Â  The 
  â€œWindsor Green Condominiums Rules and Regulationsâ€ make individual owners responsible 
  for costs and repairs to their condominiums and for any resultant damage to 
  any adjacent unit.Â  Owners are also responsible for damage caused by their tenants.Â Â Â  

On December 27, 2000, Windsor Green sent a letter to Allied demanding payment 
  of $524,712.09 for damage to the common area of the condominium complex caused 
  by the fire.Â  Windsor Green asserted Allied was contractually liable for the 
  damage because Windsor Green was a third-party beneficiary to the rental agreement 
  between Allied and J.B. Allen Real Estate based on paragraph K of the agreement.Â  
  That paragraph provides as follows:

DAMAGEÂ Â Â Â  K.Â  Damage to the Property caused by Resident, Residentâ€™s family 
  or guests, will be repaired and costs billed to the Resident and payable on 
  demand.Â  

After Allied refused to pay for the damage, Windsor Green filed suit against 
  Allied, Stanley Kaminski, and Honeywell International, Inc., [1]  alleging claims of negligence 
  and breach of contract.Â  
Allied later moved for summary judgment on all causes of action.Â  Some time 
  thereafter, Windsor Green moved for partial summary judgment on its claim of 
  breach of contract.Â Â Â  
Judge Steven H. John granted Alliedâ€™s motion for summary judgment on the negligence 
  claim, but denied its motion on the breach of contract claim.Â  The next day, 
  Judge John L. Breeden, Jr. granted Windsor Greenâ€™s motion for partial summary 
  judgment on the breach of contract claim and entered judgment in favor of Windsor 
  Green against Allied in the stipulated amount of $524,712.09.Â  Judge Breeden 
  found Windsor Green was a third-party beneficiary to the rental agreement and 
  thus entitled to recover for breach of contract for damage caused to the common 
  area of the condominium complex.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies 
  the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.â€Â  
  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 494, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  â€œSummary 
  judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material 
  fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  
  Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 529, 511 S.E.2d 69, 74 (1999).Â  
  â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all 
  inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light 
  most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 
  36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Allied contends the circuit court erred in finding Windsor Green was a third-party 
  beneficiary to the rental agreement between Allied and J.B. Allen Real Estate 
  and in awarding damages to Windsor Green for breach of contract.Â  We agree.
It is undisputed that Windsor Green is not a named party to the rental agreement.Â  
  â€œGenerally, one not in privity of contract with another cannot maintain an action 
  against him in breach of contract, and any damage resulting from the breach 
  of a contract between the defendant and a third party is not, as such, recoverable 
  by the plaintiff.â€Â  Bob Hammond Constr. Co. v. Banks Constr. Co., 312 
  S.C. 422, 424, 440 S.E.2d 890, 891 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œHowever, if a contract 
  is made for the benefit of a third person, that person may enforce the contract 
  if the contracting parties intended to create a direct, rather than an incidental 
  or consequential, benefit to such third person.â€Â  Id.
â€œThe main guide in contract interpretation is to ascertain and give legal effect 
  to the intentions of the parties as expressed in the language of the lease.â€Â  
  Gilbert v. Miller, 356 S.C. 25, 30, 586 S.E.2d 861, 864 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (holding it was clear the lease language evidenced no intent to make the plaintiff, 
  either as a guest or a tenant, a third-party beneficiary by imposing a duty 
  in tort on the landlord to prevent a tenantâ€™s dog from injuring another).Â  
â€œIf a contractâ€™s language is clear and capable of legal construction, this 
  Courtâ€™s function is to interpret its lawful meaning and the intent of the parties 
  as found in the agreement.â€ Â Id. at 30-31, 586 S.E.2d at 864.Â  â€œA clear 
  and explicit contract must be construed according to the terms the parties have 
  used, with the terms to be taken and understood in their plain, ordinary, and 
  popular sense.â€Â  Id. at 31, 586 S.E.2d at 864.
The circuit court rejected Alliedâ€™s argument that the rental agreement in this 
  case could not be interpreted to indicate the partiesâ€™ intention to bestow third-party 
  benefits upon Windsor Green.Â  The court noted condominiums are creatures of 
  statute; thus, the rental agreement must be interpreted in view of the provisions 
  of the South Carolina Horizontal Property Regime Act.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Section 27-31-120 of the Horizontal Property Act states â€œ[a]ny conveyance or 
  lease of an individual apartment is deemed to also convey or lease the undivided 
  interest of the owner in the common elements, both general and limited, appertaining 
  to the apartment without specifically or particularly referring to same.â€Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 27-31-120 (1991).Â  
As noted above, paragraph K of the rental agreement provided:Â  â€œDamage to the 
  Property caused by Resident, Residentâ€™s family or guests, will be repaired and 
  costs billed to the Resident and payable on demand.â€Â  â€œPropertyâ€ was not specifically 
  defined in the rental agreement.
The term â€œpropertyâ€ is defined in the Horizontal Property Act as including 
  â€œ(1) the land whether leasehold or in fee simple and whether or not submerged, 
  (2) the building, all improvements, and structures on the land, in existence 
  or to be constructed, and (3) all easements, rights, and appurtenances belonging 
  thereto.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-31-20(k) (Supp. 2003).
The circuit court found Allied had agreed to pay for any damage to the common 
  areas under paragraph K of the rental agreement by applying the Horizontal Property 
  Actâ€™s definition of â€œpropertyâ€ to the undefined term â€œpropertyâ€ appearing in 
  paragraph K and by reading â€œpropertyâ€ to include the common areas.Â  
Although the circuit court noted the rental agreement contained no specific 
  language conferring third-party beneficiary rights upon Windsor Green, it found 
  that Windsor Green was nevertheless a third-party beneficiary to the contract 
  â€œsince Windsor Green is the entity which maintains and controls the ownership 
  interests of the common elementsâ€ and because Allied agreed to be financially 
  responsible for damage to the â€œpropertyâ€ caused by it or its guests, with the 
  term â€œpropertyâ€ encompassing the common elements.
We find the circuit court erred in its interpretation of the Horizontal Property 
  Act.Â  Section 27-31-120 does no more than make the lease of an individual condominium 
  unit serve to also lease the ownerâ€™s undivided interest in the common elements 
  to the lessee, whether or not use of the common elements is addressed in the 
  lease.Â  Thus, a lessee has the same right to use the common areas of the condominium 
  complex, such as the hallways, the stairways, etc., as has the owner.Â  
In any case, even if section 27-31-120 and the definition of â€œpropertyâ€ as 
  used in the Horizontal Property Act are applied to the rental agreement, nothing 
  in the language of the contract itself implies any contractual duty on the part 
  of Allied to be liable for damage to anyone other than to J.B. Allen Real Estate 
  on behalf of the owners, the Reitzels.Â  No third-party beneficiary status is 
  created absent an intent by the parties to confer a substantial benefit on Windsor 
  Green.Â  Since we find no evidence of an intent to benefit Windsor Green, we 
  hold the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to Windsor Green on 
  its claim for breach of contract. 
As an alternative sustaining ground, the circuit court further ruled that, 
  while Windsor Green was not specifically mentioned in the rental agreement, 
  a condominium owner and a lessee cannot enter into a lease for the conveyance 
  of a leasehold interest without also creating reciprocal contractual duties 
  and obligations between the homeownersâ€™ association and the lessee despite the 
  lack of privity.Â  Since the ownerâ€™s undivided interest in the common areas passes 
  with the lease pursuant to the Horizontal Property Act, any rights Windsor Green 
  would have to pursue a recovery from the owner for damages to the common areas 
  attach to the lessee by virtue of the lease agreement; therefore, the circuit 
  court reasoned, Windsor Green is a third-party beneficiary of the rental agreement 
  to the extent Allied assumed obligations of the owners with respect to damage 
  to the common areas. [2] Â  
We do not think a rental agreement between a condominium owner and the ownerâ€™s 
  tenant by which the tenant voluntarily agreed to pay the owner for any 
  property damage caused by the tenant, his family, or guests, goes so far as 
  to make the homeowners association a third-party beneficiary of the contract, 
  notwithstanding the fact that, by law, the tenant has the right to use the common 
  areas.Â  Under this rationale, a homeownersâ€™ association could directly hold 
  a tenant contractually responsible for assessments, association dues, or any 
  other expenses even though the parties did not intend this result by virtue 
  of entering into a rental agreement.
Based on the foregoing, the order granting summary judgment to Windsor Green 
  on its claim for breach of contract isÂ  
REVERSED.
ANDERSON and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Honeywell International, Inc. is the successor corporation to Allied 
    Signal, Inc.Â  Where appropriate, a reference to Allied shall include Honeywell 
    International.

 
   [2]  Â The circuit court based its 
    ruling on section 27-31-120 of the Horizontal Property Act, as well as the 
    supreme courtâ€™s decision in Davenport v. Cotton Hope Horizontal Property 
    Regime, 333 S.C. 71, 508 S.E.2d 565 (1998), while noting Davenport 
    was factually distinguishable.Â  
  In Davenport, the 
    lessee sued the condominium association after he fell down a stairway at night 
    in an area where the lights were not working.Â  The supreme court cited its 
    earlier holding in Murphy v. Yacht Cove Homeowners Association, 289 
    S.C. 367, 345 S.E.2d 709 (1986) that a member of a condominium association 
    may bring a tort action against the association for failing to properly maintain 
    the common elements.Â  The holding in Murphy coupled with section 27-31-120 
    led the court to conclude that a lessee could bring an action in 
    tort against the property regime for its failure to maintain the common 
    areas.Â  Davenport, 333 S.C. at 88, 508 S.E.2d at 574.Â  The current 
    appeal does not involve a tort claim; rather, it concerns contractual liability.Â  
    Consequently, we find Davenport inapposite.

title: Horry County State Bank v. Flemington Properties
description: In this civil action, the Court reviews the discretionary authority reposed in a circuit judge under Rule 24(a), SCRCP, in a motion to intervene as a third party.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ex Parte: Horry County State Bank, Appellant.
In Re: Ken's Cabana, LLC and Winner's World, 
        Inc. both d/b/a Winner's World Tours, a joint venture, Plaintiffs,
v.
Flemington Properties, LLC, North Myrtle 
        Beach Marine & Boatworks, Inc., Rack Pack, Inc., RAM Corp., Inc., 
        C&B Properties, Inc. and Stardancer Casino, Inc., Defendants,
of whom Flemington Properties, LLC and 
        North Myrtle Beach Marine & Boatworks, Inc. are Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No.Â Â Â  3885
Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed November 
  1, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Carroll D. Padgett, of Loris, for Appellant.
        Kathryn M. Cook, of N. Myrtle Beach, for Respondents.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Horry County State Bank (the Bank) appeals the trial 
  judgeâ€™s denial of its motion to intervene pursuant to Rule 24(a)(2), SCRCP in 
  a case involving the termination of a nonexclusive easement held by Kenâ€™s Cabana, 
  LLC (Kenâ€™s Cabana) on which the Bank held a mortgage.Â  Because we find the trial 
  judge did not abuse his discretion in finding the Bankâ€™s interest was adequately 
  represented, we affirm.Â Â  Â 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This case arises from the termination of a nonexclusive parking easement at 
  the North Myrtle Beach Marina (the Marina).Â  Susan and Bruce Robertson (the 
  Robertsons) were the owners of the Marina through their company, Rack Pack, 
  Inc.Â  The Robertsons, as individuals, owned the River Boat Restaurant, located 
  next to the Marina.Â  
In May of 1999, the Robertsons 
  sold the .14 acre River Boat Restaurant property to Kenâ€™s Cabana.Â  At the same 
  time, the Robertsonsâ€™ company, Rack Pack, Inc., granted a nonexclusive parking 
  easement on a 1.3 acre lot to Kenâ€™s Cabana.Â  The easement provides:

Failure to obtain the consent of Rack Pack, Inc., its successors 
  and/or assigns, . . . to any transfer or assignment of the rights granted to 
  Kenâ€™s Cabana, LLC hereunder, shall terminate the rights granted hereunder.Â  
  Further, the use of the paved parking lot . . . for any purpose other than parking 
  in conjunction with an evening restaurant/lounge/nightclub business (evening 
  being defined as the hours between 4:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.) . . . shall result 
  in the termination of the parking rights granted hereunder.Â  

Nothing in the terms of the easement required the owner 
  of the parking lot to give the Bank notice prior to termination of the easement, 
  or the right to cure if the easement was violated.Â  
In connection with the purchase of the restaurant property, 
  the Bank issued Kenâ€™s Cabana a $448,000 loan secured by a mortgage covering 
  both the restaurant site and the easement.Â  The Bank did not require Kenâ€™s Cabana 
  to notify it if the easement was terminated.Â Â  
On January 23, 2001, Flemington Properties, LLC (Flemington) 
  purchased the Marina property from Rack Pack, Inc. and became the owner of the 
  lot on which Kenâ€™s Cabana held its parking easement.Â  At the same time, Rack 
  Pack, Inc. sold the assets of the Marina to North Myrtle Beach Marina and Boatworks, 
  Inc.Â  Flemington and North Myrtle Beach Marina and Boatworks, Inc. (Flemington/Boatworks) 
  have a common principal, Bill Bartus.Â  
Sometime in late 2001 or early 2002, Kenâ€™s Cabana entered 
  into a joint venture with Winnerâ€™s World, Inc. to operate a casino boat out 
  of the restaurant property.Â  In addition, Kenâ€™s Cabana was operating a lunch 
  business out of the restaurant earlier than 4:00 p.m.Â  Both of these actions 
  violated the terms of the easement. 
Based on these violations, Flemington/Boatworks terminated Kenâ€™s Cabanaâ€™s parking 
  easement by letter on January 29, 2002.Â  Subsequently, Flemington/Boatworks 
  posted restricted parking signs in the Marina parking lot.Â  Kenâ€™s Cabana, Winnerâ€™s 
  World, Inc., and Winnerâ€™s World Tours (collectively referred to as Kenâ€™s Cabana) 
  initiated this action on February 7, 2002 against Flemington/Boatworks, alleging 
  civil conspiracy, unfair trade practices, violations of the Fifth and Fourteenth 
  Amendments, inverse condemnation, and violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust and 
  Clayton Acts.Â  Flemington/Boatworks answered and counterclaimed seeking a declaratory 
  judgment affirming their termination of Kenâ€™s Cabanaâ€™s easement.Â  Flemington/Boatworks 
  then filed a motion for summary judgment which was heard on January 30, 2003. 

The trial judge granted the motion for summary judgment in favor of Flemington/Boatworks 
  and filed an order to that effect on February 24, 2003.Â  Kenâ€™s Cabana filed 
  a motion to reconsider on March 5, 2003, and a hearing was set for May 27, 2003.Â  
  The Bank first learned of the litigation on May 22, 2003.Â  It promptly filed 
  a motion to intervene pursuant to Rule 24(a)(2), SCRCP, along with a motion 
  to set aside the summary judgment order.Â  The motion to reconsider and the Bankâ€™s 
  motions were heard together on May 27, 2003. The trial judge ruled from the 
  bench, denying all three motions.Â  The Bank appeals the denial of its motion 
  to intervene.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The standard of review for a Rule 24(a)(2) motion is whether the judge abused 
  his discretion in granting or denying the motion.Â  S.C. Tax Commâ€™n v. Union 
  County Treasurer, 295 S.C. 257, 260, 368 S.E.2d 72, 74 (Ct. App. 1988) (citation 
  omitted).Â  â€œOn reviewing the trial judgeâ€™s decision as to whether adequacy of 
  representation exists, we must appraise all of the circumstances of a particular 
  case as to whether interests sufficiently overlap so as to deny intervention.â€Â  
  Berkeley Electric Co-op., Inc. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 302 S.C. 186, 
  191, 394 S.E.2d 712, 715 (1990).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Intervention is a procedural device whereby a third party who is not a named 
  party in an existing lawsuit, but who has an interest in its outcome, may become 
  a party to the action.Â  See Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 826 (7th ed. 
  1999).Â  Intervention may be of right or permissive; intervention of right is 
  governed by Rule 24(a), SCRCP, which is modeled after the federal rule.Â  Intervention 
  should be liberally granted, particularly where judicial economy will be promoted 
  by the declaration of rights of all parties who may be affected.Â  See 
  Berkeley Electric at 189, 394 S.E.2d at 714.Â  However, this does not 
  mean intervention should always be granted.Â  Instead, â€œwe must consider the 
  pragmatic consequences of a decision to permit or deny intervention and avoid 
  setting up rigid applications of Rule 24(a)(2).â€Â  Id.Â  â€œEach case will 
  be examined in the context of its unique facts and circumstances.â€Â  Id.Â  

Rule 24(a) provides:

Upon timely application anyone shall be permitted to intervene 
  in an action: (1) when a statute confers an unconditional right to intervene; 
  or (2) when the applicant claims an interest relating to the property or transaction 
  which is the subject of the action and he is so situated that the disposition 
  of the action may as a practical matter impair or impede his ability to protect 
  that interest, unless the applicantâ€™s interest is adequately represented by 
  existing parties.Â  

Thus, a party seeking intervention under Rule 24(a)(2) must: (1) establish 
  timely application; (2) assert an interest relating to the property or transaction 
  which is the subject of the action; (3) demonstrate that it is in a position 
  such that without intervention, disposition of the action may impair or impede 
  its ability to protect that interest; and (4) demonstrate that its interest 
  is inadequately represented by other parties.Â  Ex Parte Reichlyn, 310 
  S.C. 495, 427 S.E.2d 661 (1993).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The parties do not dispute that the Bank timely filed for intervention and 
  has an interest in the subject of the underlying action.Â  At issue is whether 
  Kenâ€™s Cabana adequately represented the Bankâ€™s rights. [1] Â  
The burden of demonstrating inadequacy of representation is on the applicant.Â  
  Berkeley Electric at 191, 394 S.E.2d at 715.Â  This burden may be satisfied 
  by a showing that the representation of the applicantâ€™s interest â€œmay beâ€ inadequate.Â  
  Id. (citation omitted).Â  
In Sagebrush Rebellion, Inc. v. Watt, 713 F.2d 525 (9th Cir. 1983), 
  the leading case on intervention of right, the court articulated a set of factors 
  for determining when an absent partyâ€™s interest is adequately represented.Â  
  The court considered â€œwhether the [existing party] will undoubtedly make all 
  of the intervenorâ€™s arguments, whether the [existing party] is capable of and 
  willing to make such arguments, and whether the intervenor offers a necessary 
  element to the proceedings that would be neglected.â€Â  Id. at 528 (citations 
  omitted).Â  Subsequently, in Berkeley Electric, our supreme court adopted 
  the following Sagebrush factors for determining the adequacy of representation:

(1) whether the existing parties will undoubtedly make all of the intervenorâ€™s 
  arguments; (2) whether the existing parties are capable and willing to make 
  such arguments; and (3) whether the intervenor offers different knowledge, experience, 
  or perspective on the proceedings that would otherwise be absent.Â  

Berkeley Electric 
  at 191, 394 S.E.2d at 715.Â  We find the Bank has failed to demonstrate its interest 
  was not adequately represented by Kenâ€™s Cabana. 
The trial judge found 
  that the Bankâ€™s interest was adequately represented because â€œKenâ€™s Cabana has 
  vigorously defended against the termination of the easement,â€ and the interests 
  of the Bank and Kenâ€™s Cabana were essentially the same.Â  On appeal, the Bank 
  offers nothing to convince us otherwise.Â  The Bank addresses no arguments or 
  defenses that were not made by Kenâ€™s Cabana and points to no unique knowledge, 
  experience, or perspective that the Bank could bring to the proceedings.Â  It 
  simply does not address the Sagebrush factors.
Instead, the Bank asserts 
  Kenâ€™s Cabana â€œmay have different intentionsâ€ than the Bankâ€”i.e., Kenâ€™s Cabana 
  â€œmay desire to sell the restaurant or even declare bankruptcy,â€ whereas the 
  Bank is concerned with protecting its security interest.Â  While there is nothing 
  in the record to suggest Kenâ€™s Cabana is planning to sell the restaurant or 
  declare bankruptcy, even if there were, this argument fails to address whether 
  or not Kenâ€™s Cabana has adequately represented the Bankâ€™s interest in the easement.Â  
  If representation could be shown inadequate by the mere possibility that two 
  parties could have different intentions, little would be left of the doctrine 
  of adequacy of representation.Â  
Commentators have noted 
  that adequacy of representation cases generally fall into one of three categories.Â  
  See 7C Charles A. Wright, Arthur R. Miller & Mary K. Kane, Federal 
  Practice and Procedure Â§ 1909, at 318-49 (2d ed. 1986).Â  First are cases 
  where â€œthe interest of the absentee is not represented at allâ€ or where â€œall 
  existing parties are adverse to him.â€Â  Id. at 319.Â  In these situations 
  there is an obvious lack of adequate representation.Â  At the other extreme are 
  cases where â€œthe interest of the absentee is identical with that of one of the 
  existing parties or there is a party charged by law with representing the interest 
  of the absentee.â€Â  Id.Â  at 324.Â  Examples of this second category include 
  class actions and cases where an executor, administrator, trustee, or other 
  formal fiduciary represents the interest of the absent party.Â  Id.Â  In 
  between these two extremes is the third category consisting of situations where 
  â€œthe interests of the absentee, and of the party thought to represent him, are 
  different, though perhaps similar.â€Â  Id. at 346. The case sub 
  judice falls into this third category.Â  
By focusing on the possibility 
  that the Bank and Kenâ€™s Cabana might have different intentions, the Bank apparently 
  would limit the denial of intervention, if at all, to that second category of 
  cases where the interests of the parties are identical.Â  However, that is not 
  the law in South Carolina.Â  Instead, we avoid â€œsetting up rigid applications 
  of Rule 24(a)(2)â€ and take each case â€œin the context of its unique facts and 
  circumstances.â€Â  Berkeley Electric at 191, 394 S.E.2d at 715.Â  Adequacy 
  of representation is determined by the Sagebrush factors.Â  Essentially, 
  we look to â€œwhether the absentee is likely to have anything of his own to say 
  that will be of value.â€ See Wright & Miller at 350.Â  The Bank points 
  to nothing additory or instructive it would bring to the dispute, but merely 
  reiterates that it has an interest.Â  
The crux of the underlying 
  case is whether Kenâ€™s Cabana will be able to continue to use the easement.Â  
  The Bankâ€™s mortgage on the parking easement is only as good as Kenâ€™s Cabanaâ€™s 
  right to use it.Â  As the trial judge found, â€œThe rights and defenses of the 
  Bank rise and fall with the acts and omissions of their mortgagor, Kenâ€™s Cabana.â€Â  
  They share the same interest and objective.Â Â Â  
In S.C. Tax Commâ€™n 
  v. Union County Treasurer, 295 S.C. 257, 368 S.E.2d 72 (Ct. App. 1988), 
  we affirmed the trial courtâ€™s denial of the South Carolina Tax Commissionâ€™s 
  application for intervention precisely because we were â€œunable to discern from 
  the Commissionâ€™s argument that its ultimate objective in th[e] case [was] different 
  from that of the Auditor and Treasurer.â€Â  Id. at 260-61, 368 S.E.2d 74.Â  
  There, the underlying action arose when Milliken & Company sued the Treasurer 
  and Auditor of Union County to collect over $87,000 in taxes paid under protest 
  to Union County.Â  The Tax Commission had exempted a Milliken manufacturing establishment 
  located in Union County from ad valorem taxes.Â  The Union County 
  Auditor and Treasurer levied a tax against Milliken that the county characterized 
  as a nonexempt municipal tax rather than an exempt county tax.Â  The trial judge 
  denied the South Carolina Tax Commissionâ€™s application for intervention.Â  In 
  affirming, we concluded: 

The burden to show that the representation may be inadequate 
  is on the applicant.Â  3B J. Moore, Mooreâ€™s Federal Practice Section 24.07[4] 
  (2d ed. 1987).Â  WHEN AN APPLICANT FOR INTERVENTION AND AN EXISTING PARTY 
  HAVE THE SAME INTERESTS OR ULTIMATE OBJECTIVE IN THE LITIGATION A PRESUMPTION 
  ARISES THAT ITS INTERESTS ARE ADEQUATELY REPRESENTED AND THE APPLICATION SHOULD 
  BE DENIED UNLESS A SHOWING OF INADEQUATE REPRESENTATION IS MADE BY DEMONSTRATION 
  OF ADVERSITY OF INTEREST, COLLUSION, OR NONFEASANCE.Â  . . . [T]he County 
  Officersâ€™ objective was to retain the tax for the county and [the Commissionâ€™s] 
  objective is to have the court rule the tax was not a county tax from which 
  Millikenâ€™s property is exempt.Â  We see no difference of interest.
. . . .
The Tax Commission has made no convincing showing the representation of its 
  interest may be inadequate.Â  It seems to argue the County Officersâ€™ interest 
  in a determination of the issue is local while its interest is statewide.Â  We 
  fail to appreciate this distinction in the context of this case.Â  Regardless 
  of how the partiesâ€™ interests are characterized, the Commission and the County 
  Officers seek the same outcome in the case.Â  

Id. at 260-61, 
  368 S.E.2d at 74 (emphasis added).Â  
Similarly, we see no difference 
  of interest here.Â  Both Kenâ€™s Cabana and the Bank seek the same outcome in the 
  case: retention of the easement.Â  Kenâ€™s Cabana obviously wants to retain parking 
  for its customers, and it trenchantly contended against the easementâ€™s termination.Â  
  The Bankâ€™s security interest in the easement exists only so long as Kenâ€™s Cabana 
  is allowed to use the easement.Â  Both parties want to preserve the easement 
  to enhance the value of the restaurant property.Â  Apodictically, the parties 
  seek the same outcome. 
Berkeley Electric 
  offers an instructive example of an intervenor satisfying the Sagebrush 
  adequacy of representation factors.Â  302 S.C. 186, 394 S.E.2d 712.Â  The underlying 
  lawsuit in Berkeley Electric arose when Berkeley Electric sued Mt. Pleasant 
  over the right to provide electrical services to a newly annexed area of the 
  town.Â  South Carolina Electric & Gas (SCE & G) moved to intervene, but 
  the trial judge denied its motion.Â  Our supreme court reversed, finding:

SCE & G has raised certain issues outside the existing pleadings.Â  
  SCE & G has also plead several special defenses to Berkeley Electricâ€™s complaint.Â  
  Additionally, SCE & G may be able to assert certain defenses that Mt. Pleasant 
  may or may not be able to raise.Â  SCE & G also has the ability to bring 
  a different perspective or experience to the proceeding that would otherwise 
  be absent.Â  For example, SCE & G has extensive experience in the area of 
  territorial service questions which arise after annexation.Â  

Id. at 191-92, 
  394 S.E.2d at 715-16.Â  
Contrastively, the Bank 
  has failed to raise, argue, or even mention any defense not already asserted 
  by Kenâ€™s Cabana.Â  The Bank had no right to notice or right to cure upon breach 
  of the terms of the easement and thus has no independent grounds to defend the 
  termination of the easement.Â  The Bank does not point to any area of expertise 
  it could bring to address the termination of the easement.Â  It does not address 
  the Sagebrush factors at all.Â  
The Bank cites Thomasson 
  v. Ocean Point Golf, Inc., 300 S.C. 29, 386 S.E.2d 282 (Ct. App. 1989), 
  for support.Â  Thomasson involved a bankâ€™s intervention in a suit between 
  the lessor and lessee of a golf course.Â  The bank was the assignee of the lesseeâ€™s 
  right to receive dues from the Fripp Island Club.Â  A dispute arose between the 
  lessor and lessee of the golf course, and the lesseeâ€™s right to payment of dues 
  was one of the contended issues.Â  The trial judge allowed the bankâ€™s intervention, 
  and we affirmed, stating: 

[W]e find no abuse of discretion in this case. . . . Thomasson 
  makes no convincing argument that the disposition of the suit would not impair 
  or impede [the bank]â€™s ability to protect [its] interest, nor has it convinced 
  us that the bankâ€™s interest was adequately represented by other parties to the 
  suit.Â  We find no error in the order granting intervention.Â  

Id. at 33, 386 
  S.E.2d at 285.Â  
In this case the trial 
  judge found that the Bankâ€™s interest was competently and adequately represented.Â  
  His order states that Kenâ€™s Cabana vigorously defended against termination of 
  the easement.Â  Further, the Bank has offered nothing to show that Kenâ€™s Cabanaâ€™s 
  representation was inadequate.Â  Therefore we find no abuse of discretion.Â  
CONCLUSION
Cognizant that intervention 
  should be liberally granted, we come to the ineluctable conclusion that the 
  denial of the motion to intervene in this case was properly decided by the circuit 
  judge.Â  The Bank and Kenâ€™s Cabana share the same ultimate objective and seek 
  the same outcome.Â  Based on his fact-intensive review, the trial judge found 
  that adequate, competent, and dynamic representation of the Bankâ€™s interest 
  occurred.Â  Moreover, the Bank has proffered nothing pertinent to the Sagebrush 
  factors.Â  We find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion by denying the 
  Bankâ€™s motion to intervene.Â  Accordingly, the judgment of the trial court is 

AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, 
  JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â 


 
   
    [1]  Because this case turns on adequacy of representation, we need not 
    address whether intervention is necessary to prevent the impairment or impediment 
    of the Bankâ€™s mortgage.Â

title: Estate of Roger D. (Bill) Prince v. Gardner
description: In this fee dispute case, this court affirms the circuit court's grant of summary judgment in favor of Appellant's attorney.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Louise P. Majstorich, Personal Representative 
        for the Estate of Roger D. (Bill) Prince, Appellant,
v.
John P. Gardner Jr., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
Sidney T. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3886
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  November 1, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        
Louise P. Majstorich, of Myrtle Beach; 
  for Appellant.
Lawrence B. Orr, of Florence; for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  In this fee dispute case, Roger D. Prince [1]  appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment 
  in favor of his attorney, John P. Gardner, Jr.Â  We affirm. 
  [2] 

FACTS 
In May 1991, a Florence County jury convicted Prince of solicitation to commit 
  murder, conspiracy, and accessory before the fact of murder.Â  The trial 
  judge granted Princeâ€™s motion for a new trial as to the charge of accessory 
  before the fact of murder.Â  Prince appealed his convictions to the supreme 
  court.Â  The State appealed the trial judgeâ€™s grant of a new trial for the accessory 
  charge. 
In addition to his two appellate attorneys, Prince retained Gardner for $25,000 
  on March 1, 1993, to argue half of the oral argument before the supreme court.
On April 19, 1993, the supreme court heard oral arguments and considered Gardnerâ€™s 
  motion for a new trial based on after-discovered evidence.Â  The supreme 
  court issued an opinion on December 13, 1993, in which it affirmed Princeâ€™s 
  convictions, reversed the grant of a new trial as to the accessory charge, and 
  remanded the case for sentencing.Â  State v. Prince, 316 S.C. 57, 447 
  S.E.2d 177 (1993).
On February 4, 1994, Prince filed a petition for rehearing, a motion to stay 
  sentencing/remittitur, and a motion for a new trial based on after-discovered 
  evidence.Â  Prince paid Gardner an additional $7,500 to arrange a meeting 
  with Attorney General Travis Medlock to discuss the new trial motion.Â  Medlock 
  declined to re-open the case.
During this time, Prince retained Jack Swerling to file a supplemental petition 
  for rehearing, a motion to stay sentencing/remittitur, and a motion for a new 
  trial.
On August 26, 1994, the supreme court denied the petition for rehearing and 
  the motion for a new trial.Â  On the same date, the court issued the remittitur.Â  
  The next day, Prince was informed of the courtâ€™s decision.Â  Prince then 
  contacted Gardner and paid him $5,000 to arrange for his sentencing date to 
  be delayed until he completed his ongoing treatment for cancer.
On August 29, 1994, Gardner filed with the supreme court a motion to stay Princeâ€™s 
  sentencing date until Prince completed his cancer treatments on October 22, 
  1994.Â  Because the remittitur had been issued, the supreme court returned 
  the motion for lack of jurisdiction.Â  Upon discovering that his sentencing 
  date could not be delayed, Prince absconded for eleven months until he was apprehended. 

While incarcerated, Prince sent Gardner a letter on February 8, 1999, informing 
  Gardner that he intended to seek the return of the fees that had been paid.Â  
  In the letter, Prince expressed his dissatisfaction with Gardnerâ€™s representation, 
  particularly his failure to obtain the favorable ruling that he had guaranteed.
On March 23, 1999, Prince filed an application for the resolution of the disputed 
  fees with the South Carolina Fee Disputes Board.Â  An assigned member issued 
  an opinion, finding the stated fee was â€œfair and equitable based upon all of 
  the surrounding facts and curcumstantces [sic].â€Â  Prince appealed this decision 
  to the full panel.Â  After a hearing, the Fee Dispute Hearing Panel issued its 
  decision on December 2, 1999, in which it found â€œthe fees charged by [Gardner] 
  were reasonable and the complaint is without merit.â€ 
Subsequently, Prince appealed the Panelâ€™s decision to the circuit court.Â  In 
  response, Gardner moved to dismiss the appeal on the following grounds:Â  (1) 
  Prince failed to properly serve the appeal; (2) the appeal was untimely; and 
  (3) the statute of limitations had expired prior to the filing of his claim 
  with the Fee Disputes Board.Â  Circuit Court Judge Edward Cottingham granted 
  Gardnerâ€™s motion and dismissed the appeal with prejudice. Â 
On June 16, 2000, Prince filed suit against Gardner, alleging causes of action 
  for:Â  breach of contract; excessive fees/unjust enrichment; breach of fiduciary 
  duty; negligence; fraud, deceit, and misrepresentation; and intentional infliction 
  of emotional distress.Â  Gardner moved for summary judgment on the grounds:Â  
  (1) the complaint failed to state a cause of action; (2) Princeâ€™s claims were 
  barred by the statute of limitations; and (3) Princeâ€™s claims were barred by 
  having submitted them to the Fee Disputes Board.
After a hearing, Circuit Court Judge Sidney Floyd issued an order on February 
  23, 2001, granting summary judgment in favor of Gardner.Â  Judge Floyd primarily 
  granted the motion on the statute of limitations ground, finding Prince knew 
  or should have known that he had a cause of action against Gardner on or before 
  August 29, 1994.Â  He further held the cause of action for excessive fees was 
  barred by the previous resolution by the Fee Disputes Board.Â  Finally, he ruled 
  a cause of action for an attorneyâ€™s failure to achieve a guaranteed result is 
  not recognized in South Carolina.Â  See Holy Loch Distribs., Inc. v. 
  Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 26, 531 S.E.2d 282, 285 (2000) (holding no cause 
  of action exists in South Carolina for legal malpractice based on breach of 
  express warranty to obtain a specific result).
On March 16, 2001, Prince appealed the order to this court 
  [3]  and filed a motion for reconsideration in the circuit court.Â  After 
  a hearing on the motion for reconsideration, Circuit Court Judge John Milling 
  [4]  issued an order on July 23, 2001, in which he denied the motion on 
  the statute of limitations ground.
On November 26, 2001, Prince appealed this order and Judge Floydâ€™s order dated 
  February 23, 2001. [5] Â  On the 
  same day, Prince sent Judge Milling a letter in which he stated that Judge Floyd 
  had failed to rule on his motion to supplement his pleadings in response to 
  Gardnerâ€™s motion for summary judgment.
On January 22, 2002, Judge Milling again denied Princeâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  
  He ruled that Princeâ€™s motion to supplement his pleadings was untimely.Â  He 
  further found that even if the motion had been timely, it did not provide a 
  basis to reverse Judge Floydâ€™s order granting summary judgment in favor of Gardner.Â  
  
  Prince appealed this order on February 26, 2002.
STANDARD OF REVIEW 
Summary judgment is appropriate when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to 
  interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, 
  show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving 
  party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  â€œIn 
  determining whether any triable issues of fact exist for summary judgment purposes, 
  the evidence and all the inferences that can be reasonably drawn from the evidence 
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Cunningham 
  v. Helping Hands, Inc., 352 S.C. 485, 491, 575 S.E.2d 549, 552 (2003).
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies 
  the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.â€Â  
  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  Therefore, 
  on appeal from an order granting summary judgment, this court will review all 
  ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in 
  a light most favorable to the nonmoving party below.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 
  346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
DISCUSSION 
Prince argues the circuit 
  court [6]  erred in granting summary 
  judgment in favor of Gardner based on the statute of limitations.Â  He contends 
  the court erred in applying a subjective standard of the discovery rule.Â  Under 
  an objective standard, Prince asserts he was not neglectful of his rights.Â  
  Because the purpose of the discovery rule is to guard against those who fail 
  to enforce their rights with reasonable diligence, he contends he should not 
  be precluded from pursuing the causes of action against Gardner. 
  [7] Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Actions for breach of 
  contract and personal injuries that arise after April 5, 1988, must be commenced 
  within three years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(1), (5) (Supp. 2003).Â  The discovery 
  rule, as outlined in section 15-3-535, provides that â€œthe statute of limitations 
  begins to run when a cause of action reasonably ought to have been discovered.Â  
  The statute runs from the date the injured party either knows or should have 
  known by the exercise of reasonable diligence that a cause of action arises 
  from the wrongful conduct.â€ Dean v. Ruscon Corp., 321 S.C. 360, 363, 
  468 S.E.2d 645, 647 (1996); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-535 (Supp. 2003) (â€œExcept 
  as to actions initiated under Section 15-3-545, all actions initiated under 
  Section 15-3-530(5) must be commenced within three years after the person knew 
  or by the exercise of reasonable diligence should have known that he had a cause 
  of action.â€); see Santee Portland Cement Co. v. Daniel Intâ€™l Corp., 
  299 S.C. 269, 271-72, 384 S.E.2d 693, 694-95 (1989) (extending the discovery 
  rule to contract actions while recognizing only certain statutes have â€œbuilt 
  inâ€ discovery provisions within the statute itself), overruled on other grounds 
  by Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc. v. Crane Natâ€™l Vendors Div. of 
  Unidynamics Corp., 319 S.C. 556, 462 S.E.2d 858 (1995); Mills v. Killian, 
  273 S.C. 66, 70, 254 S.E.2d 556, 558 (1979) (holding the discovery rule applies 
  to professional negligence causes of action).Â Â Â Â  
Â â€œThe â€˜exercise of reasonable 
  diligenceâ€™ means the injured party must act with some promptness where the facts 
  and circumstances of an injury place a reasonable person of common knowledge 
  and experience on notice that a claim against another party might exist.â€ True 
  v. Monteith, 327 S.C. 116, 119, 489 S.E.2d 615, 616-17 (1997).Â  â€œThe date 
  on which discovery should have been made is an objective, not subjective, question.â€ 
  Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 333 S.C. 714, 719, 511 
  S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œIn other words, whether the particular plaintiff 
  actually knew he had a claim is not the test.Â  Rather, courts must decide whether 
  the circumstances of the case would put a person of common knowledge and experience 
  on notice that some right of his has been invaded, or that some claim against 
  another party might exist.â€Â  Id.
Viewing the evidence in 
  the light most favorable to Prince, we find Prince knew or should have known 
  that he had a claim against Gardner on August 29, 1994, the day Prince admits 
  Gardner last represented him.Â  As evidenced by his complaint and affidavits, 
  Prince was dissatisfied with Gardnerâ€™s representation on each of the three occasions 
  that he performed work.Â  Based on this deficient performance, Prince felt that 
  he had been defrauded of the fees that had been paid.Â  Specifically, 
  Prince claimed Gardnerâ€™s â€œshockingly poor performance and presentation [before 
  the supreme court] was totally responsible for the adverse decision.â€Â  Prince 
  was aware of the unfavorable decision on December 13, 1993.Â  Prince also believed 
  that his payment of $7,500 to Gardner in February 1994 was excessive given Gardner 
  only arranged a meeting with Attorney General Travis Medlock regarding the new 
  trial motion.Â  Finally, when Gardner failed to obtain a stay of Princeâ€™s 
  sentencing on August 29, 1994, Prince felt he had been â€œscammedâ€ out of another 
  $5,000.Â  Â  
Even though Gardnerâ€™s 
  representation of Prince was completed on August 29, 1994, Prince waited until 
  June 16, 2000, to file suit against him.Â  Applying the discovery rule under 
  an objective standard, we hold Princeâ€™s suit was untimely and, thus, barred 
  by the three-year statute of limitations.
Accordingly, the grant 
  of summary judgment in favor of Gardner is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, 
  JJ., concur.


 
   
    [1] Â Â  During the pendency of the appeal, Prince passed away.Â  His sister, 
    Louise P. Majstorich, now represents his interests as the personal representative 
    of the estate. 

 
   
    [2] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issue 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

 
   
    [3] Â  Because the notice of appeal was premature, this court dismissed 
    it without prejudice.

 
   
    [4] Â  Judge Milling assumed the case upon Judge Floydâ€™s retirement.

 
   [5]  Â Â Prince alleged he had not received a copy of 
    Judge Millingâ€™s order until November 16, 2001. 

 
   
    [6] Â Â  Although Prince has specifically appealed the two circuit court 
    judgesâ€™ orders, we refer to the judges as the circuit court in the interest 
    of clarity.

 
   
    [7] Â Â  We note that Prince has not appealed the circuit courtâ€™s remaining 
    grounds for the grant of summary judgment.Â  This fact alone would warrant 
    our affirming the grant of summary judgment as to the excessive fees cause 
    of action and the breach of contract cause of action.Â  See Charleston 
    Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 
    871 (2000) (stating an unappealed ruling is the law of the case); Brading 
    v. County of Georgetown, 327 S.C. 107, 113, 490 S.E.2d 4, 7 (1997) (recognizing 
    that where a decision is based on more than one ground, an appellate court 
    will affirm unless the appellant appeals all grounds because the unappealed 
    ground will become the law of the case).Â  Because, however, the statute of 
    limitations ruling is applicable to the other causes of action, we decide 
    to address the issue with respect to all of the causes of action raised by 
    Prince.
