title: Glasscock Company, Inc. v. Sumter County
description: This case concerns two contracts for waste disposal services Sumter County entered into with Waste Management, Inc., and whether the award of those contracts complied with local and state laws requiring the competitive procurement of public services.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Glasscock Company, Inc., Waste Industries, 
        Inc. and Wilson MacEwen, Appellants,
v.
Sumter County, Frank Williams, Jr., Naomi 
        Sanders, Carol Burr, Charles Edens, Louis Fleming, James Campbell, Rudy 
        Singleton (members of the County Council) and Waste Management, Inc., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
G. Wells Dickson, Jr., Special Referee

Opinion No. 3887
Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed November 
  1, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
M. M. Weinberg, Jr., of Sumter, for Appellants.
Harold W. Jacobs, of Charleston, Johnathan Werber Bryan, 
  of Sumter and W. Thomas Lavender, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This case concerns two contracts for waste disposal 
  services Sumter County entered into with Waste Management, Inc., and whether 
  the award of those contracts complied with local and state laws governing the 
  competitive procurement of public services.Â  The special referee concluded the 
  Countyâ€™s award of these contracts complied with all applicable procurement laws.Â  
  We agree and affirm.
FACTS 
In 1998, Sumter County Council decided to close the Sumter 
  County landfill and contract with a private firm to have the Countyâ€™s solid 
  waste transported and disposed of in another landfill in neighboring Richland 
  County.Â  To this end, the County Council issued requests for proposals seeking 
  sealed bids from private firms for two service contracts.Â  One contract covered 
  equipping and operating â€œconvenience centersâ€ located throughout the County 
  where residents could dispose of their household garbage (the â€œcollection contractâ€).Â  
  The other contract provided for the transportation of municipal solid waste 
  to a Richland County landfill (the â€œtransportation contractâ€).Â  
Chambers Waste Systems of South Carolina was the successful bidder for both 
  contracts.Â  The collection contract entered into with Chambers was for a period 
  of three years with two one-year options, while the transportation contract 
  was for an initial five-year term with two five-year renewal options.Â Â  However, 
  shortly after entering into these contracts with the County, Chambers Waste 
  Systems was acquired by Waste Management.Â Â  
For the next three years, the County and Waste Management continued to operate 
  under the original contracts.Â  By 2001, Waste Managementâ€™s business in the Midlands 
  had grown substantially.Â  To more effectively service their customers, Waste 
  Management sought to construct or acquire a regional waste transfer station 
  in which solid waste from within a multi-county area could be collected and 
  then transported to its Richland County landfill.Â  In furtherance of this plan, 
  a representative of Waste Management presented a written proposal to Sumter 
  County for the purchase of the Sumter County Transfer Station for $1,300,000.Â  
  The proposal also called for the extension of the collection and transportation 
  contracts through the year 2021. 
The Waste Management proposal was presented in February 2001 to County Council 
  in executive session.Â  Following this closed-door meeting, a council member 
  gave a copy of the Waste Management proposal to James T. Glasscock, Jr., president 
  of Glasscock Company, Inc., a company which is also in the waste disposal business. 
  Â Mr. Glasscock thereafter began contacting council members, insisting 
  the proposed contract extension be put out for competitive bid.Â  However, because 
  Waste Managementâ€™s proposal, and particularly its terms, had been improperly 
  disclosed, County Council determined the competitive sealed bidding process 
  urged by Glasscock would be tainted and therefore was no longer feasible.Â Â  

Council took up the matter of the Waste Management proposal at its next scheduled 
  meeting on April 10, 2001.Â  Several alternatives to the proposal were considered.Â  
  After some debate, Council passed resolutions to amend the collection and transportation 
  contracts by, among other things, extending their terms as proposed by Waste 
  Management and agreeing to â€œsellâ€ its solid waste transfer station to Waste 
  Management. [1]   
At its next scheduled meeting on April 24, 2001, Council gave first reading 
  approval to two proposed ordinancesâ€”specifically, Ordinances 01-436 and 01-437â€”authorizing 
  the contract extensions that had been approved by resolution on April 10, 2001.Â  
  Following second and third readings at the next two scheduled Council meetings 
  and a public hearing, the ordinances approving the contract amendments were 
  formally adopted on May 22, 2001.Â  The addenda to the Waste Management contracts 
  were subsequently executed. Â These contract extensions were an integral 
  part of the agreement to convey the transfer station to Waste Management.Â  Sumter 
  Countyâ€™s sale of the transfer station is not challenged on appeal.Â  Glasscock 
  seeks only the rescission of the contract extensions authorized by Ordinances 
  01-436 and 01-437.
SCOPE OF REVIEW 
An action for rescission of a contract is equitable in nature.Â  Brown v. 
  Greenwood School Dist. 50 Bd. of Trustees, 344 S.C. 522, 525, 544 S.E.2d 
  642, 643 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  While this court may review the record and make findings 
  based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence as provided in the 
  landmark case of Townes Associates v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 
  86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976), the material facts in this case are undisputed.Â  
  The issues before us on appeal concern only the legal question of whether the 
  County Councilâ€™s actions complied with local and state procurement laws.
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compliance with Sumter County Procurement Ordinance 
Glasscock first argues the referee erred in finding the County Council complied 
  with the Sumter County Procurement Ordinance 
  [2]  provisions governing the purchase of county service contracts.Â  We 
  disagree.
Section 2-221 of the Procurement Ordinance provides, in pertinent part, that 
  â€œcompetitive sealed bidding shall be used for all purchases . . . [w]here the 
  purchase price exceeds twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00).â€ Â§ 2-221(1).Â  
  Specifically exempted, however, from the competitive procurement requirements 
  are â€œ[c]ontracts that are specifically approved by a county ordinance.â€ Â§ 2-186(A)(1). 
  Â Â 
As noted above, Ordinances 01-436 and 01-437 approving the 
  amendment of the Waste Management contracts were duly passed by County Council 
  in May 2001.Â  Glasscock claims, however, these ordinances were ineffective to 
  exempt the contract amendments from competitive bidding under section 2-186.Â  
  He argues the contracts were effectively executed and binding upon the County 
  several weeks before the ordinances were passed when County Council passed its 
  initial resolution approving the contract amendments.Â  Therefore, according 
  to Glasscock, the contract amendments were void because they were not entered 
  into in strict compliance with the Procurement Ordinance.Â  Glasscock argues 
  the subsequent passage of Ordinances 01-436 and 01-437 was simply an attempted 
  remedial measure to imbue illegal contracts with the appearance of compliance 
  with the Procurement Ordinance.Â  
In support of his argument that it was the resolution and 
  not the ordinances that effectively bound the County, Glasscock places heavy 
  emphasis on the trial testimony of County Council member Rudy Singleton.Â  Singleton 
  testified that, based on his informal discussion with several other fellow council 
  members, he thought the Waste Management contract amendments were a â€œdone dealâ€ 
  when the resolution was passed on April 10, 2001. 
We find this argument is without merit.Â  Glasscock misapprehends 
  the generally accepted function of resolutions as distinguished from ordinances 
  in the conduct of local government legislation.Â  Resolutions do not normally 
  have mandatory or binding effect.Â  Rather, the passage of resolutions is generally 
  considered to be merely directory.Â  See Central Realty Corp. v. Allison, 
  218 S.C. 435, 446, 63 S.E.2d 153, 158 (1951) (holding that â€œit seems to be well 
  settled that a resolution is not a law, and in substance there is no difference 
  between a resolution, order, and motionâ€); see also 56 Am Jur. 
  2d Municipal Corporations Â§ 296 (2000) (commenting that â€œan ordinance 
  is distinctively a legislative act, while a resolution may simply be an expression 
  of opinion or mind concerning some particular item of business coming within 
  the legislative bodyâ€™s official cognizance . . .â€); 62 C.J.S. Municipal 
  Corporations Â§ 247 (Supp. 2004) (commenting that â€œa resolution ordinarily 
  is an act of a special or temporary character, not prescribing a permanent rule 
  of government, but is merely declaratory of the will or opinion of a municipal 
  corporation in a given matter . . .â€).
It is clear here that the adoption of the resolution was 
  simply a first step in the process of County Councilâ€™s formal, public consideration 
  of the contract amendments.Â  As noted above, following the adoption of the resolution, 
  the contract amendments proposed by the resolution were given formal first, 
  second, and third readings at public County Council sessions followed by a public 
  hearing on the matter noticed several weeks in advance.Â  Indeed, in order to 
  carry out this public process, the Council and Waste Management needed to reach 
  at least a tentative understanding regarding the details of any contract amendments 
  that would ultimately be agreed upon.Â  Such an understanding was needed prior 
  to the period for public comment and hearings in order for specific ordinances 
  to begin their journey through the deliberative process.
Accordingly, we concur with the refereeâ€™s ruling that County 
  Council complied with the applicable provisions of the Sumter County Procurement 
  Ordinance in adopting the contract amendments through the enactment of Ordinances 
  01-436 and 01-437.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Compliance with State 
  Statutory Procurement Law
Alternatively, Glasscock contends that, even if County Councilâ€™s 
  adoption of the contract amendments complied with the requirements of the Sumter 
  County Procurement Ordinance, that Procurement Ordinance is contrary to and 
  preempted by applicable state procurement laws. 
Section 11-35-50 of the South Carolina Consolidated Procurement 
  Code provides that â€œ[a]ll political subdivisions of the State shall adopt ordinances 
  or procedures embodying sound principles of appropriately competitive procurement 
  no later than July 1, 1983.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-35-50 (Supp. 2003).Â  Glasscock 
  contends the Sumter County Procurement Ordinanceâ€™s exemption from competitive 
  bid requirements for contracts that are specifically approved by county ordinance 
  violates the mandate of section 11-35-50 and is therefore invalid.Â  As such, 
  Glasscock argues, County Councilâ€™s adoption of the contract amendments by enacting 
  Ordinances 01-436 and 01-437 violated the state procurement code.Â  We disagree.Â  

First, we note that section 11-35-50 does not impose a specific 
  requirement that all public procurement in our state be carried out by way of 
  a single, narrowly defined procedure.Â  While its mandate that all government 
  bodies adopt some form of competitive procurement procedures is unambiguous, 
  the statuteâ€™s broad directive that the processes chosen â€œembody[] sound principles 
  of appropriately competitive procurementâ€ clearly was intended to afford local 
  governments needed flexibility to determine what is â€œappropriately competitiveâ€ 
  in light of the public business they must transact.Â  
The state government, for exampleâ€”operating under the same 
  general approach prescribed by section 11-35-50â€”provides certain exceptions 
  to the competitive sealed bid rule for state purchases in its procurement code. 
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-35-710 (Supp. 2003).Â  We find no logic or consistency 
  in recognizing some flexibility at the state level while handcuffing local governments 
  with none. 
That local governments should be afforded a reasonable degree 
  of latitude in devising their own individual procurement ordinances and procedures 
  is entirely consistent with our stateâ€™s now firmly rooted constitutional principle 
  of â€œhome rule.â€Â  By the ratification of Article VIII of our state constitution 
  in 1973, substantial responsibility for city and county affairs devolved from 
  the General Assembly to the individual local governments.Â  â€œ[I]mplicit in Article 
  VIII is the realization that different local governments have different problems 
  that require different solutions.â€ Hospitality Assâ€™n of South Carolina v. 
  County of Charleston, 320 S.C. 219, 230, 464 S.E.2d 113, 120 (1995); see 
  also Knight v. Salisbury, 262 S.C. 565, 571, 206 S.E.2d 875, 877 
  (1974) (opining that the constitutional amendment providing for home rule was 
  â€œprompted by the feeling that Columbia should not be the seat of county government, 
  and that the General Assembly should devote its full attention to problems at 
  the state levelâ€).Â  In addition, Article VIII mandates that â€œall laws concerning 
  local government shall be liberally construed in their favor.â€Â  S.C. Const. 
  art. VIII, Â§ 17.Â  Coordinate with the principle of home rule, South Carolina 
  Code section 4-9-25 empowers counties to enact regulations, ordinances, and 
  other laws provided they are consistent with the general laws of our state. 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-25 (Supp. 2003).
Glasscock urges this Court to construe section 11-35-50 as 
  mandating sealed competitive bids in virtually every instance of public procurement.Â  
  This approach would effectively strip our stateâ€™s local governments of any flexibility 
  in determining the competitive procurement policies and procedures appropriate 
  for them to adopt.Â  Indeed, such a reading of section 11-35-50 runs wholly contrary 
  to the home rule authority vested in local government by our constitution.Â  
  We reject Glasscockâ€™s argument.
In reaching this conclusion, we do not intend to diminish 
  the vital role sealed bidding procurement procedures play in ensuring open, 
  accountable government.Â  To be sure, we recognize the general applicability 
  of competitive sealed bids under the Sumter County Procurement Ordinance.Â  In 
  the present case, however, we address only a narrow exception to that general 
  rule.Â  Whether a contract should be approved by ordinance and therefore exempt 
  from the sealed bid requirement is a function of County Councilâ€™s discretion, 
  the exercise of which they are accountable for as publicly elected officials.Â  
  â€œIn reviewing the discretionary decision of a legislative body, our courts have 
  been loath to substitute their judgment for that of elected representatives. 
  Such decisions â€˜should not be upset on appeal unless [they are] arbitrary, unreasonable, 
  in obvious abuse of discretion, or in excess of lawfully delegated power.â€™â€ 
  Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 555-56, 590 S.E.2d 338, 351 
  (Ct. App. 2003) (quoting Smith v. Georgetown County Council, 292 S.C. 
  235, 238-39, 355 S.E.2d 864, 866 (Ct.App.1987)).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons we conclude the contract amendments 
  at issue here were validly executed in accordance with the procedures prescribed 
  by the Sumter County Procurement Ordinance.Â  Furthermore, we hold that the exemption 
  from sealed competitive bidding provided for under the Sumter County Procurement 
  Ordinance is valid under our stateâ€™s mandate that all government bodies employ 
  appropriately competitive procurement procedures.Â  The order of the special 
  referee is therefore
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., 
  concur.

 
  [1]  Although termed a â€œsale,â€ the then proposed conveyance of the transfer 
    station provided that title to the property would revert to the County in 
    the event Waste Management â€œceases to operate the transfer station at the 
    termination of the either of two existing contracts, or any extensions thereof, 
    either through the passage of time or default by [Waste Management] in its 
    performance of the two existing contracts . . . .â€Â  (footnote omitted). 

 
  [2]  Sumter County Code Â§Â§ 2-171 to -268.Â

description: In this felony driving under the influence case, Appellant argues the indictment was insufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction on the circuit court.

  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
  
    
      
        
          The State, Respondent,
        
      
    
  
  v.
  
    
      
        
          Allison Campbell a/k/a Allison McSwain, Appellant.
        
      
    
  
  
  Appeal From Oconee County
  Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge
  
  Opinion No. 3888
  Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 8, 2004
  
  AFFIRMED
  
  
    
      
        
          David F. Stoddard, of Anderson, for Appellant.
          Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster,Â  Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,Â  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,Â  Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Allison Campbell appeals after pleading guilty to one count of felony driving under the influence (â€œD.U.I.â€) resulting in death.Â  Following her guilty plea, the trial court sentenced Campbell to six years in the State Department of Corrections, imposed a fine of $10,000, and ordered payment of restitution in the amount of $8,571.50 for the victimâ€™s funeral expenses.Â  On appeal, Campbell argues the indictment was insufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction.Â  We affirm.
  FACTS
  On April 10, 2002, Campbell and the victim attended a party for Campbellâ€™s nephew.Â  After leaving the party they went to a local bar and played pool.Â  Upon leaving the bar, with Campbell driving and the victim riding in the passenger seat, the couple began to drive down Highway 59 towards Seneca, South Carolina.Â  
  After encountering a curve, Campbell ran approximately 200 feet off the road and failed to make any attempt to steer the car back onto the highway.Â  The passenger side of the car collided with the end of a guardrail, the collision being violent enough to tear away a good portion of the passenger side of the car including the passenger door itself.Â  The victim was ejected from the vehicle, his head struck the guardrail, and he died at the scene.Â  
  Campbell testified that she did not remember the accident, but only waking up and realizing the victim was no longer in the car.Â  When EMS arrived at the scene, Campbell informed them she thought she had hit a deer.Â  She also kept talking to the victim although he was not there.Â  Both the EMS and Law Enforcement personnel on the scene indicated Campbell was under the influence and that she smelled strongly of alcohol.Â  Campbell was taken to Oconee Hospital where she refused a legal blood alcohol test.Â  The doctor at the hospital, however, opined that she was under the influence.Â  
  On June 18, 2002, an Oconee County grand jury indicted Campbell for violation of section 56-5-2945(A)(2) of the South Carolina Code for felony D.U.I. that resulted in death.Â  On July 23, 2003, Campbell moved to have counsel relieved, but the request was withdrawn when the court informed her she would have to proceed pro se should the motion be granted.Â  On July 23, 2003, the State called the case for trial at which time Campbell pled guilty to the charge.Â  
  LAW/ANALYSIS
  On appeal, Campbell argues the indictment was insufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction on the court.Â  We disagree.
  In a criminal case, the circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction to convict a defendant only if: â€œ(1) there has been an indictment which sufficiently states the offense; (2) there has been a waiver of the indictment; or (3) the charge is a lesser-included charge of the crime charged in the indictment.â€Â  Cutner v. State, 354 S.C. 151, 155, 580 S.E.2d 120, 122 (2003).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[t]he lack of subject matter jurisdiction can be raised at any time, can be raised for the first time on appeal, and can be raised sua sponte by the court.â€Â  State v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 103, 107, 572 S.E.2d 309, 311 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing State v. Brown, 351 S.C. 522, 570 S.E.2d 559 (2002)).
  Section 56-5-2945 of the South Carolina Code provides in pertinent part the following:
  
    (A) A person who, while under the influence of alcohol, drugs, or the combination of alcohol and drugs, drives a vehicle and when driving does any act forbidden by law or neglects any duty imposed by law in the driving of the vehicle, which act or neglect proximately causes great bodily injury or death to a person other than himself, is guilty of a felony and upon conviction must be punished:
    
      (2) by a mandatory fine of not less than ten thousand one hundred dollars nor more than twenty-five thousand one hundred dollars and mandatory imprisonment for not less than one year nor more than twenty-five years when death results.
    
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2945(A) & (A)(2) (Supp. 2003).
  The indictment alleged the following:
  
     That Allison L. Campbell did in Oconee County on or about April 10, 2002, drive a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, drugs, or a combination of both, and did an act forbidden by law and/or neglected a duty imposed by law, to wit:Â  a Motor Vehicle Accident caused by the Defendantâ€™s driving while under the influence of alcohol, which act and/or neglect proximately cuased [sic] the death of Kevin Tremain Shook in violation of Â§56-5-2945(A)(2)â€¦.
  
  (emphasis in original).
  Campbell contends the indictment is fatally flawed because it â€œfails to allege an act forbidden by law or neglect of a duty imposed by law.â€Â  Specifically, she argues that although the indictment includes the statutory language â€œdid an act forbidden by law and/or neglected a duty imposed by law,â€ it fails to describe the specific act and/or neglected duty on which the State relied to support the felony D.U.I. charge.Â  
  The general rule regarding the adequacy of an indictment is that â€œ[a]n indictment is sufficient if the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead an acquittal or conviction thereon.â€Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 364, 580 S.E.2d 785, 791 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[t]he true test of the sufficiency of an indictment is not whether it could be made more definite and certain, but whether it contains the necessary elements of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently apprises the defendant of what he must be prepared to meet.â€Â  Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995) (citing State v. Munn, 292 S.C. 497, 357 S.E.2d 461 (1987)).
  An indictment is sufficient when it uses substantially the same language contained in the statute prohibiting the crime charged, or when it is described in such a way that the nature of the charge is plainly understood.Â  State v. Reddick, 348 S.C. 631, 635, 560 S.E.2d 441, 443 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When examining the sufficiency of an indictment, â€œthis court should â€˜look at the issue with a practical eye in view of the surrounding circumstances.â€™â€Â  State v. Barnett, 358 S.C. 199, 202, 594 S.E.2d 534, 535 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 130, 437 S.E.2d 75, 78 (1993)).Â  
  Even a cursory reading of the indictment in the current case shows it contains virtually identical language to that contained in the statute defining the offense.Â  In addition, because Campbell pled guilty, it is clear she was aware of the nature of the charge against her.Â  A thorough review of the record discloses no indications of uncertainty in regard to the crime with which she was charged.Â  Accordingly, as the indictment adequately alleged the elements of the offense, we find the indictment was sufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction on the circuit court.Â  
  Because we find the indictment sufficient, we need not address Campbellâ€™s remaining argument concerning double jeopardy.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling appellate court need not review remaining issues when disposition of prior issues are dispositive); Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œ[t]he appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in Record on Appealâ€).Â  
  AFFIRMED.
  GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

title: Rimer v. Rimer
description: This appeal challenges the family courtâ€™s alimony award as excessive. This court finds the family court did not abuse its discretion in its award of alimony and its order is therefore affirmed.

  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
  
  
    
      
        
          Daniel P. Rimer, Appellant,
        
      
    
  
  v.
  
    
      
        
          Kimberly V. Rimer, Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  Appeal From Florence County
  Â Wylie H. Caldwell, Jr., Family Court Judge
  
  Opinion No. 3889
  Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed November 8, 2004
  
   AFFIRMED
  
  
    
      
        
          Robert E. Lee, Charles L. McLain, III, and Amy Anderson Wise, all of Florence, for Appellant.
          Evander G. Jeffords, of Florence, and John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  KITTREDGE, J.: In this appeal from the family court, we are asked to determine whether the alimony award was excessive.Â  We find the family court did not abuse its discretion in its award of alimony and therefore affirm.
  FACTS
  Daniel P. Rimer (Husband) and Kimberly V. Rimer (Wife) were married in 1977 and separated in 2002.Â  Citing irreconcilable differences, Husband brought the present action for separate maintenance and support.Â  The family court issued an order distributing the marital property, setting the terms of custody and support for the Rimersâ€™ minor child,[1] and awarding alimony to Wife.Â  The only issue raised in this appeal is whether the alimony award was excessive in light of the partiesâ€™ respective incomes and expenses.
  The relevant facts concerning the Rimersâ€™ financial circumstances are as follows.Â  Husband has been employed by the same company, CSX Railroad, throughout the marriage.Â  With only a high school education, Husband worked his way up through the ranks at the railroad to a position of substantial responsibility as a mechanical superintendent.Â  This job has required that Husband work long hours and be available to travel to the railroadâ€™s various East Coast shop locations.Â  At the time of the final hearing, Husbandâ€™s reported gross income was approximately $7,000 per month.[2]
  During the marriage, Wife was primarily occupied as a stay-at-home mother, raising the children and tending to the household affairs.Â  Like Husband, she too did not pursue education or training beyond high school.Â  Her work experience outside the home has been limited. Early in the marriage she was briefly employed as a bookkeeper and restaurant hostess.Â  More recently, she has worked part time as a substitute teacher at a local private school, earning approximately $266 per month.Â  The family court concluded, however, that Wife was underemployed, and found she was â€œcapable of at least minimum wage employment,â€ which, at the time, equaled approximately $900 income per month. 
  The family court granted Wife possession of the marital home.Â  Wifeâ€™s exclusive use and enjoyment of the house, however, was only to continue as long as the Rimersâ€™ minor son continued to live at home while finishing high school.Â  Once their son left for college (anticipated in fall of 2003), the court order required that the house be listed for sale at its appraised value and sold, with the equity to be split sixty percent to Husband and forty percent to Wife.[3]Â  In the interim, however, Wife assumed responsibility for paying all of the household bills, including the monthly mortgage payment.Â  
  Bearing full financial responsibility for the home, Wife faced substantial monthly expenses.Â  The monthly mortgage payment alone was $1,046.Â  This payment and her other household and living expenses totaled $3,496 per month according to the estimates accepted by the family court.Â  Wife clearly could not make ends meet on her ownâ€”even assuming, as the family court did, she was capable of finding full-time, minimum wage employment. 
  The family court awarded Wife alimony of $2,600 per monthâ€”the amount necessary to cover the shortfall between the minimum wage income of $900 per month and Wifeâ€™s monthly expenses of nearly $3,500.Â  From this alimony award Husband now appeals.
  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  The amount of alimony is within the sound discretion of the family court judge and should not be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion is shown. Smith v. Smith, 264 S.C. 624, 628, 216 S.E.2d 541, 543 (1975). An abuse of discretion occurs either when a court is controlled by an error of law, or where the order is based upon findings of fact lacking evidentiary support. Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).
  LAW/ANALYSIS
  Husband claims the family court abused its discretion in setting alimony at $2,600 per month, arguing the amount is excessive in light of Wifeâ€™s income potential and his ability to pay.Â  While a close question is presented, we conclude the award is within the broad discretion accorded the family court.
  The purpose of an alimony award is to serve as a substitute for the support which is normally incident to the marital relationship, thereby placing the supported spouse, as nearly as is practical, in the same position he or she enjoyed during the marriage. Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511, 516-17, 586 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App. 2003). Alimony should not dissuade a spouse, to the extent possible, from becoming self-supporting. McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 599, 506 S.E.2d 1, 9 (Ct. App. 1998). The family court has broad discretion in determining the amount of permanent alimony, and there is no single, fixed standard to use in making that determination. See, e.g., Graham v. Graham, 253 S.C. 486, 491, 171 S.E.2d 704, 707 (1970) (opining that â€œ[t]he amount of alimony . . . cannot be determined by any mathematical formula but is a matter resting within the sound discretion of the trial judge . . . â€).Â Â  All relevant factors must be considered and weighed by the court.Â  South Carolina Code section 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2003) lists some of the factors a family court must consider when deciding whether and how much alimony to award, including, but not limited to: the duration of the marriage, the educational background of the parties, the employment history and earning potential of the parties, the standard of living established during the marriage, and the current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties. 
  In the present case, the nub of Husbandâ€™s argument is that the family court erred in its assessment of some of the critically relevant factors concerning the partiesâ€™ current and prospective financial situation.Â  Specifically, Husband asserts: (1) the court should have found Wife had greater earning potential than merely the minimum wage; (2) the court should have judged his ability to pay alimony based on his net monthly income rather than his gross income; and (3) the court should not have included among Wifeâ€™s expenses the monthly mortgage payment on the former marital home because of the homeâ€™s imminent, court-ordered sale.Â  We address each of these points separately below.
  1.Â  Wifeâ€™s Earning Potential
  Husband claims the family court arrived at an unrealistically low estimate of Wifeâ€™s prospective earning capacity.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.
   As described above, Wifeâ€™s training and work experience over the course of their twenty-five-year marriage were limited.Â  In recent years, she has only worked â€œonce or twice a monthâ€ as a substitute teacher.Â  Her last full-time employmentâ€”as a bookkeeper performing â€œgeneral office dutiesâ€ for a hotelâ€”was approximately twenty years ago.Â  Husband maintains this work experience should have translated, as of the date of the final hearing, into a higher-paying managerial or professional level job today.Â  We do not share his confidence.Â  The paper-driven back office of decades past has been largely replaced by computer-based management tools.Â  If Wife seriously desired to reenter that line of work, she would almost certainly need training in order to become competent in todayâ€™s technology-intensive office environment.Â  We do, however, recognize that Wife has considerable potential in the broader workforce.Â  In this regard, we agree with the family court judge who recognized that Wife â€œis an attractive, bright woman and although her education and training are limited, she is capable, at the age of 47, of getting a reasonable job or obtaining training or education to qualify her for even better employment.â€[4] 
  For these reasons, we cannot fault the family court for taking a less sanguine view of Wifeâ€™s employment prospects.Â  We find the court acted within its discretion by imputing only the minimum wage to Wife.
  2.Â  Husbandâ€™s Income
  Husband argues the family court should have considered only his net monthly income of $4,700 rather than his gross income of $7,000.Â  We find no error.Â  Included among the factors listed in section 20-3-130(C) that the family court â€œmust considerâ€ when determining the appropriate amount of alimony are â€œthe current and reasonably anticipated earnings of both spouses.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)(6).Â  The statute makes no distinction between net and gross income, and no such distinction has been imposed by our courts.Â  While the family court judge referenced Husbandâ€™s gross income, a careful review of the record reveals that proper consideration was given to his net income.Â  The suggestion that the family court simply relied on Husbandâ€™s gross income without regard to his net pay finds no traction in this record.[5]Â Â  
  Parties petitioning for alimony awards are, of course, free to argue that a spouseâ€™s earnings be calculated in any manner they think justified.Â  We leave it largely to the family court judgeâ€™s discretion, however, to determine what is appropriate in light of the circumstances of each individual case.Â  Formulaic principles and bright-line rules will only hinder the ability of family court judges to reach an equitable result in this individualized, fact-intensive area of law.[6]
  3.Â  Sale of the Former Marital Home
  Husband next argues the family court improperly determined Wifeâ€™s expenses.Â  He claims the court should not have included the $1,046 monthly mortgage payment for the former marital home among Wifeâ€™s expenses, arguing that obligation would be short-lived in light of the family court order that the home be sold in the fall of 2003 when their youngest son left for college.Â  While we agree the substantial mortgage payment was designed to be short-lived, the able family court judge properly declined Husbandâ€™s invitation to speculate as to Wifeâ€™s reasonable and necessary expenses following sale of the former marital residence.
  While the sale of the former marital residence was certainly contemplated in the final decree, the ultimate effect of this change of circumstances could not have been ascertained at the time of the initial award.Â  Accordingly, it would have been inappropriate for the family court to follow Husbandâ€™s suggestion and speculate as to the effect of this event on Wifeâ€™s living situation and attendant expenses. We similarly decline to modify the alimony award based on purported changed circumstances associated with the sale of the former marital residence, for we find that such request must in the first instance be presented to the family court.[7]
  This case illustrates well the competing tensions at stake when a family court judge initially rules on a matter which is modifiable upon a showing of a material change in circumstances.Â  Recognizing that the desired goal of finality is elusive in this area, our family court judges strive to recognize anticipated, foreseeable changes.Â  However, when the effect of anticipated changes is not readily ascertainable, it is inappropriate for the family court to speculate as to the effect of such anticipated changes. In such circumstances, as here, the family court should consider the effect of changed circumstances in the context of a modification action. 
  CONCLUSION
  For these reasons, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in the alimony award to Wife.Â  The family court order is therefore 
  AFFIRMED.
  HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., concur.



  [1] The parties have two children of the marriage, one of whom had already reached the age of eighteen at the time this action was initiated.


  [2] This income figure does not include substantial bonuses which Husband received in some years, ranging from $12,000 to $16,000.Â  The family court did not consider the potential for bonuses in the alimony award.


  [3] This court was informed at oral argument that the former marital residence was sold in 2003. 


  [4] It was disclosed at oral argument that Wife obtained employment as a flight attendant during the pendency of this appeal.Â  The issue of Wifeâ€™s current earnings and earning capacity is not before us.


  [5] The alimony award here is not the result of a gross versus net income approach, but is primarily the result of two factors: (1) the award of exclusive possession of the former marital residence pending the partiesâ€™ youngest childâ€™s completion of high school; and (2) the family courtâ€™s assessment of Wifeâ€™s earnings and earning capacity.


  [6] Husband had been voluntarily paying pendente lite support of $2,700 monthly to Wife.Â  Wife urges this court to rely on this fact in affirming the award of permanent alimony of $2,600 per month.Â  To do so, however, would be ill-advised.Â  Family court litigants may well confront challenges at the onset of litigation which are not present if the case proceeds to trial.Â  For example, an offer of temporary support may be motivated by a desire to reconcile the marriage.Â  Moreover, the obligation to pay pendente lite support only continues during the pendency of the litigation prior to a final determination of the matter on its merits.Â  To assign weight to the amount of support awarded pendente lite or view the award as having any precedential value at the merits hearing or on appeal would discourage parties from amicably agreeing upon temporary support for fear the slightest concession would prejudice their position at the final hearing.Â  Temporary hearings are not de facto final hearings, and we adhere to the principle that temporary orders must be without prejudice to the rights of the parties at the final hearing. 


  [7] Indeed, our law allows a supporting spouse the right to petition the family court for a reduction in alimony based upon a showing of a material change in circumstances. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1985).Â  Our ruling today does not in any way foreclose Husbandâ€™s right to pursue, as provided by law, a modification of the alimony award.

title: State v. Broaddus
description: Appellant appeals his convictions for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.  He argues the trial judge erred in admitting evidence of drug use and drug dealing as res gestae of the crimes.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
v.
Roshamel Broaddus Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3890
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  November 15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John 
  W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Edgar L. Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  
  Roshamel Broaddus appeals his convictions for murder and possession of a firearm 
  during the commission of a violent crime.Â  He argues the trial judge erred in 
  admitting evidence of drug use and drug dealing as res gestae 
  of the crimes. [1] Â  We affirm. [2]   
FACTS
During the early 
  morning hours of August 7, 1999, the body of David Christopher Briggs was found 
  in a vacant lot in Florence.Â  The victim had multiple gunshot wounds.Â  Although 
  neighbors heard gunshots during the night, no one witnessed the shooting.Â  An 
  autopsy later revealed the victim had been shot at least seventeen times, which 
  caused him to bleed to death.Â  
After receiving 
  information concerning a red Grand Am frequenting drug areas, narcotics officers 
  interviewed Dennis Rhodes, a confidential informant and the owner of the vehicle. 
  Â Rhodes told them that he had reason to believe that someone had been 
  killed in his car.Â  He stated that, on the morning of the murder, he loaned 
  his car to Broaddus.Â  According to Rhodes, the interior of the vehicle was covered 
  in blood and had bullet holes when Broaddus returned it.Â  Subsequently, the 
  investigating officers impounded and searched Rhodesâ€™s vehicle.Â  As part of 
  the continuing investigation, SLED analysis of the blood evidence confirmed 
  a DNA match with the victim.Â  Broaddus was ultimately apprehended in 
  New York where he was hospitalized as a result of another shooting incident.Â  
  A Florence County grand jury later indicted Broaddus for murder and possession 
  of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.
At trial, the State 
  called Dennis Rhodes as a witness.Â  Prior to Rhodesâ€™s testimony, Broaddusâ€™s 
  counsel moved to exclude any mention of whether Broaddus was dealing drugs on 
  the night in question.Â  Specifically, counsel argued the evidence should not 
  be admitted as part of the res gestae of the charged crimes.Â  
  He further contended the evidence would be far more prejudicial than probative 
  and should be excluded under Rule 403 of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence.Â  
  The judge admitted the evidence, finding Rhodes could describe the circumstances 
  of the night of the murder in order to give a full description of the events 
  that occurred that night, including an explanation of Rhodesâ€™s involvement with 
  Broaddus.Â  The judge concluded the testimony in question was part of the res 
  gestae of the crimes.
Rhodes testified 
  on the night of the murder he went to Tony Pickettâ€™s home where he met several 
  acquaintances including Broaddus.Â  According to Rhodes, everyone was drinking 
  and doing drugs that were supplied by Broaddus.Â  At one point during the evening, 
  Broaddus asked Rhodes if he could borrow his car.Â  Rhodes loaned his car to 
  Broaddus in exchange for cash or crack cocaine because Broaddus stated he needed 
  to make some phone calls and â€œsome deliveries.â€Â  Rhodes believed Broaddus was 
  going to make drug deliveries because he observed the supply of drugs in Broaddusâ€™s 
  hand.Â  Broaddus borrowed the car around 2:30 a.m. and returned it to Rhodes 
  at approximately 6:00 a.m.Â  When Rhodes opened the door to the vehicle, he noticed 
  blood and gunshot holes in the interior.Â  Rhodes testified that Broaddus apologized 
  for the condition of the vehicle and explained that his cousin had been shot 
  and he had taken him to the hospital.Â  Broaddus then gave Rhodes crack cocaine 
  while he and Pickett cleaned the vehicle.Â  The next day, Rhodes found a bullet 
  slug, as well as hair and scalp tissue on the passenger side of the vehicle.
The State offered 
  evidence regarding its theory about what might have precipitated the shooting.Â  
  J.C. Newsome testified he sold Broaddus a CD player a week prior to the incident.Â  
  When Broaddus inquired about the CD player, Newsome informed him that the victim 
  had it.Â  Newsome took Broaddus to the motel where the victim was staying, 
  but purposefully brought him to the wrong room when he discovered that Broaddus 
  had a gun and threatened to kill the victim.Â  Kelvin Lucas testified 
  he went to a bar with the victim on the night of the shooting.Â  During the evening, 
  the victim left the bar but returned within a short period of time.Â  Lucas testified 
  the victim seemed upset.Â  Around 4:30 a.m., the victim told Lucas that he had 
  â€œsomething to go take care ofâ€ and left the bar.Â  Lucas testified that he observed 
  the victim get into a car with Broaddus. 
The jury convicted 
  Broaddus of murder and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent 
  crime.Â  The judge sentenced him to forty years imprisonment for murder and a 
  concurrent, five-year term for possession of a weapon during the commission 
  of a violent crime.Â  Broaddus appeals.
DISCUSSION
Broaddus asserts the trial judge erred in admitting evidence of drug use and 
  drug dealing as res gestae of the crimes.Â  He contends the evidence 
  was not necessary for the presentation of the Stateâ€™s case given the presence 
  of drugs did nothing to further the explanation for the blood and bullet holes 
  that were discovered in the borrowed vehicle.Â  He further argues the evidence 
  of drug dealing and drug use did not establish a motive for the murder.Â  Although 
  we agree with Broaddus that the admission of the evidence was improper, we find 
  any error in its admission was harmless. 
â€œThe admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of 
  the trial judge, whose decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse 
  of discretion.â€Â  State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 121, 551 S.E.2d 240, 244 
  (2001).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is based 
  on an error of law.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 
  464, 467 (2000).Â Â  
â€œThe rationale underlying the res gestae theory is that evidence of other criminal 
  conduct that occurs contemporaneously with or is part and parcel of the crime 
  charged is considered part of the res gestae of that offense.â€Â  State v. 
  Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 462, 469 S.E.2d 49, 53 (1996).Â  â€œThe res 
  gestae theory recognizes evidence of other bad acts may be an integral 
  part of the crime with which the defendant is charged, or may be needed to aid 
  the fact finder in understanding the context in which the crime occurred.â€Â  
  State v. King, 334 S.C. 504, 512, 514 S.E.2d 578, 582 (1999). Under res 
  gestae, evidence of other crimes is admissible:

when such evidence â€œfurnishes part of the context of the crimeâ€ or is necessary 
  to a â€œfull presentationâ€ of the case, or is so intimately connected with and 
  explanatory of the crime charged against the defendant and is so much a part 
  of the setting of the case and its â€œenvironmentâ€ that its proof is appropriate 
  in order â€œto complete the story of the crime on trial by proving its immediate 
  context or the â€˜res gestaeâ€™â€ or the â€œuncharged offense is â€˜so linked together 
  in point of time and circumstances with the crime charged that one cannot be 
  fully shown without proving the other . . .â€™ [and is thus] part of the res gestae 
  of the crime charged.â€Â  And where evidence is admissible to provide this â€œfull 
  presentationâ€ of the offense,â€ [t]here is no reason to fragmentize the event 
  under inquiryâ€ by suppressing parts of the â€œres gestae.â€Â  

Id. at 512-13, 514 S.E.2d at 582-83 (quoting State v. Adams, 
  322 S.C. 114, 122, 470 S.E.2d 366, 370-71 (1996)).Â  
Our appellate courts have found evidence of prior drug use to be inadmissible 
  as part of the res gestae where the record does not support any 
  relationship between the charged crime and the drug use.Â  See, e.g., 
  State v. Hough, 325 S.C. 88, 92-94, 480 S.E.2d 77, 79-80 (1997) (finding 
  co-defendantâ€™s testimony regarding prior crack cocaine use did not form a part 
  of the res gestae of burglary and grand larceny where there was 
  no evidence defendant and co-defendant had smoked crack cocaine immediately 
  prior to the burglary or that the prior acts were â€œso linked together in point 
  of time and circumstancesâ€ as to be required for a full presentation of the 
  Stateâ€™s case); State v. Smith, 309 S.C. 442, 446-47, 424 S.E.2d 496, 
  498-99 (1992) (holding evidence of defendantâ€™s prior drug use should have been 
  excluded where it was unrelated to the crimes of murder and armed robbery and 
  was not contemporaneous with the victimâ€™s murder); State v. Bolden, 303 
  S.C. 41, 43, 398 S.E.2d 494, 494-95 (1990) (concluding evidence that defendant 
  was a social user of crack cocaine should have been excluded where evidence 
  was â€œnot essential to a full presentation of the Stateâ€™s case, nor was it so 
  intimately connected with the crimes charged that its introduction was appropriate 
  to complete the story of the crimeâ€). 
If, however, the evidence of drug use is â€œinextricably intertwinedâ€ with the 
  crime at issue, our appellate courts have found it to be admissible.Â  See, 
  e.g., State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 122, 470 S.E.2d 366, 370-71 (1996) 
  (concluding trial judge properly admitted evidence of defendantâ€™s cocaine use 
  prior to the robbery and murder where cocaine use, which precipitated the decision 
  to commit the robbery and murder, was in close â€œtemporal proximityâ€ to the crimes, 
  the cocaine use was part of the environment of the crimes and was inextricably 
  intertwined with the crimes); State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 461-63, 
  469 S.E.2d 49, 53-54 (1996) (finding evidence of crack cocaine sale between 
  defendant and victim several hours prior to the murder was a part of the res 
  gestae of the crime where evidence of earlier sale was necessary to show 
  why the victim sought out the defendant and to explain the specific circumstances 
  surrounding the encounter); State v. Gagum, 328 S.C. 560, 564-65, 492 
  S.E.2d 822, 823-24 (Ct. App. 1997) (holding, in case involving strong-arm robbery 
  stemming from a purse snatching, evidence of defendantâ€™s offer of drugs to his 
  captors to obtain his release was admissible where the offering of the drugs 
  â€œâ€˜was so intimately connected with the crime charged that its introduction was 
  appropriate to complete the story of the crimeâ€™â€ (quoting Bolden, 303 
  S.C. at 43, 398 S.E.2d at 495)).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In this case the testimony regarding Broaddusâ€™s drug use and drug dealing â€œwas 
  not essential to a full presentation of the Stateâ€™s case, nor was it so intimately 
  connected with the crimes charged that its introduction was appropriate to complete 
  the story of the crime.â€Â  Bolden, 303 S.C. at 43, 398 S.E.2d at 495.Â  
  The testimony presented established that Broaddus threatened to kill the victim 
  because he stole the CD player that Broaddus purchased from Newsome.Â  Lucas 
  testified he observed the victim get into a car with Broaddus shortly before 
  the murder.Â  Rhodes testified that when Broaddus returned the vehicle it was 
  covered in blood and had bullet holes.Â  The decedentâ€™s blood was positively 
  matched to the evidence found in Rhodesâ€™s vehicle.Â  Thus, evidence of drug use 
  and drug dealing was not necessary for the Stateâ€™s presentation of its case.Â  
  Furthermore, the drug evidence was not inextricably intertwined with the crimes 
  charged given there was no evidence that Broaddus and the victim were involved 
  in any type of drug transaction.Â  Because the testimony did not form a part 
  of the res gestae of the crimes, the trial judge erred in admitting 
  the evidence.Â  Additionally, even assuming the testimony was relevant, its probative 
  value was outweighed by its unfair prejudice.Â  See Bolden, 303 
  S.C. at 43, 398 S.E.2d at 495 (holding even if testimony under the res 
  gestae theory is relevant, its probative value must be weighed against 
  any unfair prejudice); Rule 403, SCRE (â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be excluded 
  if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, 
  confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue 
  delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€).
However, any error 
  in the admission of the evidence was harmless.Â  â€œError is harmless where it 
  could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€Â  State v. Adams, 
  354 S.C. 361, 380, 580 S.E.2d 785, 795 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied 
  (Apr. 22, 2004).Â  When guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence 
  such that no other rational conclusion can be reached, this court should not 
  set aside a conviction because of errors not affecting the result.Â  Hill 
  v. State, 350 S.C. 465, 472, 567 S.E.2d 847, 851 (2002).Â  Newsome testified 
  that Broaddus threatened to kill the victim shortly before the murder.Â  Lucas 
  testified that he witnessed the victim get into a vehicle with Broaddus several 
  hours before the shooting.Â  Additionally, witnesses who were present when Broaddus 
  returned Rhodesâ€™s automobile testified concerning the condition of the car and 
  the presence of blood in the car.Â  The DNA from the blood in the car was a positive 
  match to the victim.Â  Furthermore, there is evidence that Broaddus absconded 
  to New York after the incident.Â  See State v. Ballenger, 322 S.C. 
  196, 200, 470 S.E.2d 851, 854 (1996) (stating flight is â€œat least some evidenceâ€ 
  of defendantâ€™s guilt).Â  
Furthermore, the 
  drug evidence is cumulative to other unobjected to testimony.Â  Specifically, 
  Van Purvis, who was present at Pickettâ€™s home, testified that Broaddus provided 
  the crack cocaine and intended to pay Rhodes with crack cocaine to borrow his 
  automobile.Â  Pickett also testified that Rhodes would be paid with crack cocaine 
  for lending his car to Broaddus.Â  See State v. Schumpert, 
  312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993) (stating that any error in admission 
  of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence is harmless); State 
  v. Johnson, 298 S.C. 496, 499, 381 S.E.2d 732, 733 (1989) (â€œThe admission 
  of improper evidence is harmless where it is merely cumulative to other evidence.â€).
CONCLUSION
We find the testimony 
  regarding drug use and drug dealing was not admissible as part of the res 
  gestae of the charged crimes.Â  We hold, however, that any error in its 
  admission was harmless.Â  Based on the foregoing, Broaddusâ€™s convictions and 
  sentences are 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â Â Â

    Pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State 
    v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), Broaddusâ€™s appellate 
    counsel filed a brief along with a petition to be relieved, stating his examination 
    of the record indicated the appeal was without merit.Â  Broaddus filed a separate 
    pro se response.Â  Following our Anders review, this court 
    ordered the parties to brief the following issue:
  
  Whether the trial court erred in admitting evidence 
    of the alleged drug usage and dealing as res gestae of the crime?
  
  This issue is now our sole appellate consideration.

 
   [2] Â Â  
    Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issue on appeal, 
    we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
