THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Patricia E. Deidun,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Richard C. Deidun,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3891
Heard September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed November 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Daniel D. Dâ€™Agostino, of York, for Appellant.
Lucy London McDow, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  In this domestic matter, Patricia 
  E. Deidun (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s final order, arguing the court erred 
  in: (1) defining a car as nonmarital property; (2) distributing the marital 
  assets and debts; (3) failing to award adequate alimony; and (4) failing to 
  award adequate attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Wife and Richard C. Deidun (Husband) were 
  married on April 23, 1977, and separated on December 17, 1999, when Husband 
  left the marital home.Â  The parties had a son during the marriage, born October 
  27, 1981.Â  Husband worked throughout the marriage, except for a seven-week period 
  in 1999 when he suffered from depression.Â Â  Wife also worked either part-time 
  or full-time jobs throughout the marriage, with the exception of two years after 
  the birth of their son.Â  Wife was the primary party responsible for caring for 
  the partiesâ€™ son, cleaning, cooking, buying the familyâ€™s food and clothes, and 
  handling the familyâ€™s finances.Â  
The parties lived in Michigan after they 
  were married.Â  In 1988, Husband accepted a position in Charlotte, North Carolina, 
  and the family moved there.Â  Husbandâ€™s North Carolina position paid him substantially 
  less than his former Michigan position.Â  The parties soon accumulated nearly 
  $33,000 in credit card debt, and Wife did not tell Husband about the debt.Â  
  Husband discovered the marital debt in 1993, and he took control over the finances.Â  
  The parties borrowed $28,000 from Wifeâ€™s father to pay off a portion of the 
  debt.Â  Two years later, Husband repaid Wifeâ€™s father for the loan, paid off 
  all of the partiesâ€™ other credit card debts, and reduced the family to one Wachovia 
  credit card which they both used.Â  At that time, Wife resumed responsibility 
  over the familyâ€™s finances. 
The parties lived a comfortable lifestyle.Â  
  They took vacations each year and enjoyed riding motorcycles.Â  Husband used 
  money inherited from his father to establish Putnam IRA accounts for himself 
  and Wife.Â  In 1996, the parties sold their Charlotte home, clearing nearly $80,000 
  in equity from the sale.Â  The couple built a 3,400 square foot home in Fort 
  Mill, South Carolina, for $253,000.Â  The parties also took out a $25,000 line 
  of credit on their new home and used $19,000 to purchase a second motorcycle.Â  

In 1999, Husband suffered from depression 
  and he took leave from work.Â  While recovering, he cleaned up his old motorcycle, 
  sold it, and gave $9,200 to Wife to pay on the line of credit used to buy the 
  new motorcycle.Â  He was informed by Wife that there was still $25,000 owing 
  on the line of credit.Â  Because the parties only used $19,000 on the line of 
  credit to purchase the new motorcycle and they had been paying on the line of 
  credit for several years, Husband was surprised.Â  When he investigated the partiesâ€™ 
  financial status, he learned that the balance on the line of credit was actually 
  $31,000, not $25,000 as Wife had told him.Â  He also learned that Wife had withdrawn 
  and spent nearly $27,000 from her Putnam IRA account without disclosing it to 
  him, and Wife had incurred nearly $7,500 in credit card debt without his knowledge.Â  
  Wife had also opened a Truliant credit union line of credit, with a balance 
  of $7,218, that Husband was not aware of.Â  The parties eventually separated 
  in December 1999 when Husband left the marital home.Â Â  
 After the parties separated in December 
  1999, they agreed to sell the marital home and Wife decided to build a new $172,000 
  home for herself and the partiesâ€™ son.Â  Wife obtained several credit cards and 
  charged nearly $19,000 before the parties entered into a consent order in March 
  2000.Â  The March 6, 2000 temporary consent agreement provided that Husband would 
  pay: child support for the partiesâ€™ seventeen-year old son; $1,000 a month in 
  alimony to Wife; all the marital bills until Wife moved from the marital home; 
  $16,300 to pay off the balance due on Wifeâ€™s car; and $75,000 to Wife to assist 
  in closing on her new home.Â  Husband liquidated his Putnam IRA account, subject 
  to a substantial early withdrawal tax penalty, and gave Wife $75,000 to put 
  towards her new home and $16,300 to pay off the balance owed on her car.Â  Wife 
  used the funds to put $43,000 down on her new home and to pay off some of the 
  credit card debt.Â  The parties sold their home in September 2000 for $286,000.Â  

At some point, Husband started a relationship with 
  another woman.Â  Husband, his paramour, and the paramourâ€™s children eventually 
  moved to California when Husband accepted a job there in 2000.Â  Wife filed a 
  summons and complaint on September 18, 2000, seeking a divorce based on Husbandâ€™s 
  adultery.Â  On November 7, 2000, a second consent order was filed memorializing 
  the partiesâ€™ agreement that Husband could have $75,000 from the sale of the 
  partiesâ€™ house, with Husbandâ€™s attorney holding the remaining funds in trust.Â  
  A third consent order was filed on December 13, 2000, in which Wife signed a 
  quit-claim deed to any home Husband purchased in California, a community property 
  state.Â  Husband voluntarily paid his sonâ€™s college tuition and purchased a car 
  for his son.Â  
This action was tried on July 11, 2001.Â  
  After hearing testimony from Wife and Husband, the family court granted Wife 
  a divorce based on Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  The court also found that Wifeâ€™s failure 
  to handle the family finances responsibly and failure to inform Husband about 
  the status of their finances or her large expenditures amounted to a form of 
  misconduct that was a contributing factor to the breakup of the marriage.Â  The 
  court found Husbandâ€™s Corvette was not marital property and ordered the marital 
  assets be split with 65% going to Husband and 35% to Wife.Â  The court also divided 
  the marital debt, awarded Wife $1,200 per month in alimony, and awarded Wife 
  $2,570 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Finally, the court ordered a qualified domestic 
  relations order to divide the marital portions of Husbandâ€™s retirement accounts 
  on a 50/50 basis.Â  
After Wife filed a motion to reconsider, the family 
  court issued a supplemental order, finding that: (1) Wife was not fiscally responsible 
  and would likely spend beyond her means, regardless of the size of award she 
  were to be given by the family court; (2) Husband voluntarily paid for the sonâ€™s 
  college expenses; and (3) Wifeâ€™s expenses cited to support her claim for additional 
  alimony appeared to be inflated by debt service on additional borrowing and 
  appeared excessive in light of Wifeâ€™s receipt of $75,000 from Husband during 
  their separation.Â  The court noted that its original order actually failed to 
  allocate marital assets 65/35 in favor of Husband, so the court ordered that 
  Husbandâ€™s attorney distribute the entire $10,240 in funds remaining from the 
  sale of the partiesâ€™ home to Wife.Â  The court refused to alter the original 
  order further.Â  Although the court intended to divide the non-pension assets 
  on a 65/35 basis, the distribution after the supplemental order amounted to 
  an approximately 59/41 allocation.
Wife timely appealed the family courtâ€™s 
  order.Â  Husband filed a motion before this court to remand the matter when he 
  learned that his taxes had been miscalculated and he owed an additional $10,002.60 
  early withdrawal penalty on the Putnam IRA account he cashed in to pay Wife.Â  
  This court granted the motion to remand on February 20, 2003, and Husband filed 
  a motion for relief from judgment before the family court pursuant to Rule 60, 
  SCRCP. [1] Â  The family court indicated at the hearing 
  that it would deny Husbandâ€™s motion, and the court refused to: grant him relief 
  from judgment; reopen the case; consider the additional $10,002.60 tax penalty 
  as marital debt; or redistribute the marital assets and debts.Â  However, the 
  May 9, 2003 written order granted Husbandâ€™s motion to the extent that the additional 
  $10,002.60 would be considered marital debt and Husband would be responsible 
  for the debt.Â  Wife appeals both the supplemental order and the order on Husbandâ€™s 
  Rule 60 motion.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this 
  court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its view of the 
  preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 
  204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not, however, 
  require this court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson 
  v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Neither is 
  the court required to ignore the fact that the family court judge, who saw and 
  heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility 
  and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 
  276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. NONMARITAL PROPERTY
Wife argues Husbandâ€™s Corvette was transmuted into 
  marital property during the marriage, and thus the family court erred in determining 
  that it was nonmarital property.Â  Alternatively, Wife asserts that she was entitled 
  to special equity from the increase in value of the Corvette during the marriage.Â  
  We disagree.
Property acquired prior to the marriage is generally 
  considered nonmarital.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(2) (Supp. 2003).Â  Although 
  nonmarital property is generally not subject to equitable distribution, the 
  other spouse may be entitled to a special equity in the property.Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(5) (Supp. 2003).Â  A spouse obtains an equitable interest in 
  improvements to property to which he or she has contributed, even if the property 
  is nonmarital.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 299, 372 S.E.2d 107, 
  113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  
Nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital 
  property.Â  In determining whether property has been transmuted, courts must 
  consider whether the property: (1) â€œbecomes so commingled with marital property 
  as to be untraceable;â€Â  (2) is titled jointly; or (3) â€œis utilized by the parties 
  in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent 
  by the parties to make it marital property.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 
  S.C. 88, 98, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001). Â â€œTransmutation is a matter 
  of intent to be gleaned from the facts of each case.â€Â  Id.Â  The burden 
  is on the spouse claiming transmutation to produce objective evidence that the 
  parties considered the property to be marital during the marriage.Â  Id.
It is undisputed that Husband purchased 
  his 1973 Corvette when it was new for $5,900, and he paid off the balance owing 
  on the car a year before the parties married.Â  Wife testified the Corvette was 
  Husbandâ€™sÂ  â€œprized possession,â€ and Husband described it as his â€œtoyâ€ and â€œweekend 
  pleasure vehicle.â€Â  With the exception of an eighteen-month period when it was 
  necessary for Husband to drive the car on a daily basis, the car was not regularly 
  used.Â  While the parties lived in Michigan, the Corvette was stored and not 
  insured during the winter months every year.Â  Husband primarily drove the Corvette, 
  although Wife occasionally drove it.Â  During the marriage, Husband maintained 
  the vehicle and made improvements to it including installing new calipers, a 
  stainless steel exhaust system, and new wheels, for a total cost of $1,500.Â  
  At the time of the final hearing, the Corvette had increased in value to $15,000.Â  
  The family court specifically held that the Corvette was the nonmarital property 
  of Husband.Â  
Despite Wifeâ€™s argument that the car was at times used 
  during the marriage by both parties, the evidence indicates the car was more 
  of a pleasure vehicle and not necessary for transportation for the parties.Â  
  Although the Corvette was maintained and insured during the marriage from the 
  partiesâ€™ joint account, to which both parties contributed, nothing indicates 
  the partiesâ€™ intentions that the Corvette change from nonmarital to marital 
  property.Â  Because this car was not used for the benefit of the marriage, we 
  find the car was not transmuted and agree with the family court that the Corvette 
  was Husbandâ€™s separate, nonmarital property.Â  
Further, there is no evidence in the record 
  to support Wifeâ€™s argument that she is entitled to special equity from the increase 
  in value of the Corvette.Â  Other than the money from the partiesâ€™ joint account, 
  Wife made no other contribution to the maintenance or improvements to the Corvette.Â  
  The evidence in the record indicates that, other than routine maintenance, the 
  cost of improvements was only $1,500.Â  Accordingly, the evidence does not support 
  Wifeâ€™s argument that she is entitled to special equity in the vehicle.Â Â  
II. EQUITABLE DISTRIBUTION
Wife argues the distribution of the partiesâ€™ assets 
  and debts was not fair and equitable because the family court did not adequately 
  consider the statutory factors and erred in finding she was guilty of economic 
  misconduct.Â  Wife also asserts the family court erred in considering additional 
  evidence concerning tax liabilities pursuant to a Rule 60, SCRCP motion.Â  We 
  disagree.
A. Fairness of the Distribution
Wife argues the family court erred in: 
  (1) finding she committed â€œeconomic misconductâ€ which led to the dissolution 
  of the marriage; (2) awarding a 59/41 distribution; and (3) failing to adequately 
  consider all the statutory factors in dividing the martial assets and debts.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
The apportionment of marital property 
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bungener 
  v. Bungener, 291 S.C. 247, 251, 353 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Section 
  20-7-472 lists fifteen factors for the court to consider in equitably apportioning 
  a marital estate.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2003); Greene v. Greene, 
  351 S.C. 329, 340, 569 S.E.2d 393, 399 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  On appeal, this court 
  looks to the overall fairness of the apportionment.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 
  296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  If the end result is 
  equitable, it is irrelevant that the appellate court would have arrived at a 
  different apportionment.Â  Id.Â Â  
Wife incurred $33,000 in credit card debt 
  without informing Husband prior to 1993, when Husband took control of the finances.Â  
  After Wife regained responsibility for the family finances and without Husbandâ€™s 
  knowledge, she increased the partiesâ€™ $25,000 line of credit to $31,000; withdrew 
  nearly $27,000 from her Putnam IRA; incurred $7,500 in credit card debt; and 
  opened a new line of credit with a balance of $7,218.Â  Wife admitted at trial 
  that she hid her expenditures, the partiesâ€™ growing debt, and her withdrawal 
  from her Putnam IRA account from Husband.Â  Wife claimed she neglected to inform 
  Husband because he had a stressful job and he did not want to be bothered with 
  the financial details.Â  Wife claimed she always spent the money on family necessities, 
  including clothing, food, and other household debt.Â  Wife incurred additional 
  credit card debt between the partiesâ€™ separation in December 1999 and the March 
  2000 temporary consent order.Â  Wife testified that she incurred those debts 
  to pay for household expenses, including nearly $2,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and 
  nearly $5,000 in Christmas gifts for their son, including ski equipment and 
  a $3,100 musical instrument.Â  Husband testified that Wifeâ€™s financial mismanagement 
  led to the breakup of the marriage.Â  
Citing McDavid v. McDavid, 333 
  S.C. 490, 511 S.E.2d 365 (1999), Wife complains that the family court erred 
  in finding her guilty of economic misconduct and in considering the economic 
  misconduct in the equitable distribution.Â  In McDavid, the husband used 
  $24,13.50 in marital funds to support his failing business during the marriage 
  without informing the wife.Â  The family court found the husbandâ€™s actions constituted 
  marital misconduct, and the court used that amount in adjusting downward the 
  husbandâ€™s share of the marital assets.Â  The supreme court affirmed this courtâ€™s 
  finding that the husbandâ€™s imprudent business decisions did not constitute marital 
  misconduct:

In accordance with [other jurisdictions], we hold poor business 
  decisions, in and of themselves, do not warrant a finding of marital â€œmisconduct,â€ 
  and that there must be some evidence of willful misconduct, bad faith, intention 
  to dissipate marital assets, or the like, before a court may alter the equitable 
  distribution award for such misconduct.Â  

McDavid, 333 S.C. at 496, 511 S.E.2d at 368 
  (emphasis added).Â  
We find McDavid may be distinguished 
  from the present case.Â  Although there is nothing in the record to indicate 
  that Wife acted with any bad faith in her spending habits, we believe McDavid 
  is more applicable to cases involving business expenditures.Â  Wifeâ€™s depletion 
  of marital funds and increase of the marital debt in the present case were not 
  to support a failing business.Â  Accordingly, we find McDavid inapplicable 
  in the present case and the family courtâ€™s consideration of Wifeâ€™s failure to 
  appropriately manage the family finances was not error.Â  
Further, we find the evidence in the record 
  supports the courtâ€™s findings that Wifeâ€™s willful habit of spending irresponsibly 
  was one factor that led to the breakup of the marriage.Â  After Wife incurred 
  substantial marital debt and Husband paid it off, she again incurred substantial 
  debt and depleted funds from a marital IRA account, without informing Husband. 
  Â She admitted that she hid the mounting debts, expenditures, and a withdrawal 
  from the IRA from Husband.Â  Other than Wifeâ€™s testimony that she spent the money 
  on the family, there is nothing in the record to show actually what the money 
  was spent on.Â  Wifeâ€™s intentional, reckless spending habits, and the associated 
  debt, placed significant stress on the partiesâ€™ marriage and led to the breakup 
  of the marriage.Â  Her spending amounted to mismanagement of the family finances 
  and to economic misconduct.Â Â  
Finally, we find the family court adequately 
  considered the statutory factors, including Wifeâ€™s financial misconduct, in 
  awarding a 59/41 division of the non-pension marital assets in favor of Husband.Â  
  A family court must consider several factors in equitably dividing marital property, 
  including: (1) the length of the marriage and the ages of the parties; (2) the 
  martial misconduct of either party; (3) the value of the marital property; (4) 
  the income and earning potential of each spouse; (5) each partyâ€™s emotional 
  and physical health; (6) the need of a spouse for training to reach his or her 
  earning potential; (7) each partyâ€™s nonmarital property; (8) retirement benefits; 
  (9) awards of alimony; (10) whether the marital home should be awarded to one 
  spouse; (11) the tax consequences of a particular distribution; (12) the existence 
  of support obligations from prior marriage; (13) liens or encumbrances on marital 
  property and any debt; (14) child custody arrangements; and (15) any other relevant 
  factor the trial court enumerates in the order.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 
  2003).
At the time of the final hearing, the parties had 
  been married twenty-two years and their only child was over the age of eighteen.Â  
  Neither party had a college education, although Husbandâ€™s specialized skills 
  made him highly marketable in his field.Â  Wife was forty-five years old, employed 
  to her potential, earned approximately $2,300 per month, and was in relatively 
  good health.Â  Husband was forty-nine years old, employed to his potential, earned 
  approximately $81,212 per year, and was in relatively good health.Â  Wife had 
  $110,980.79 in non-pension marital assets in her possession, and Husband had 
  $175,495.96 in non-pension marital assets in his possession.Â  Husband earned 
  pension benefits at two of his jobs; one of the retirement accounts was earned 
  entirely during the marriage and 80% of the other account was earned during 
  the marriage.Â  The marital debts included a $34,967 tax penalty for Husbandâ€™s 
  early withdrawal from his Putnam IRA; $7,155.86 from Wifeâ€™s Truliant line of 
  credit; $8,767.18 on Wifeâ€™s Shade Platinum credit card; $10,117.87 on Wifeâ€™s 
  MBNA credit card; a $16,149.56 lien on Wifeâ€™s car; and $11,609 in tax liability 
  from Wifeâ€™s early withdrawal from her Putnam IRA.Â Â Â  
The evidence indicates that the family 
  court adequately considered all the statutory factors in equitably dividing 
  the marital assets and debts.Â  In addition to considering the above factors, 
  the court considered Husbandâ€™s adultery, Wifeâ€™s non-economic contributions to 
  the marriage, and Wifeâ€™s economic misconduct.Â  With the exception of the tax 
  liability incurred when Wife withdrew funds from her Putnam IRA, of which Husband 
  was ordered to pay 65%, the court ordered each party be responsible for their 
  own debt.Â  Out of a total marital debt of $88,766.47, Wife was ordered to pay 
  $46,253.62 or 52%.Â  In the supplemental order, the court awarded Wife $120,220.79 
  of the total $296,716.75 in non-pension marital assets, or 41%.Â  Additionally, 
  the court granted Wife 50% of the marital portions of Husbandâ€™s retirement accounts 
  when they vested.Â  Further, the parties admitted at the oral argument of this 
  case that considering the pension award would raise Wifeâ€™s percentage of the 
  marital estate above 41%. 
Although the parties in the present case had a 
  long marriage and each party contributed financially to the marriage, we find, 
  based on the factors considered by the family court, that the actual distribution 
  of assets and debts was equitable in this case.Â Â  
B. Post-trial Evidence
Wife asserts that, upon remand from this 
  court, the family court erred in â€œreopening the case and accepting additional 
  evidenceâ€ regarding the tax penalty from the early withdrawal of Husbandâ€™s Putnam 
  IRA account.Â  We disagree.
A circuit court may relieve a party from 
  a final judgment pursuant to Rule 60 (b)(1), SCRCP, where a party shows â€œthe 
  judgment or order was induced by mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable 
  neglect.â€Â  Hillman v. Pinion ex. rel Estate of Hillman, 347 S.C. 253, 
  256, 554 S.E.2d 427, 429 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Relief from judgment under Rule 60, 
  SCRCP, rests within the sound discretion of the trial court, and the courtâ€™s 
  findings will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Thompson 
  v. Hammond, 299 S.C. 116, 119, 382 S.E.2d 900, 902-03 (1989).
During the final hearing, Husband presented 
  two un-filed tax returns prepared by his accountant.Â  One showed his estimated 
  taxes had he not cashed out his Putnam IRA.Â  The second tax return showed he 
  owed $34,967 as an early withdrawal penalty for cashing out the Putnam IRA.Â  
  The family court determined the early withdrawal penalty was a marital debt 
  and ordered Husband to pay the entire $34,967.Â Â  
After this court remanded the appeal to the family 
  court, a hearing was held on Husbandâ€™s Rule 60, SCRCP, motion for relief from 
  judgment.Â  Husband alleged that his accountant had underestimated the tax penalty 
  for the early withdrawal from the Putnam IRA account, and he learned after the 
  final divorce hearing that he owed an additional $9,132 plus $870 in interest.Â  
  He alleged the family court should consider this amount to be marital debt and 
  then recalculate the debt.Â  The family court indicated at the hearing that it 
  was not willing to alter the facts and it was denying the motion to reopen the 
  case and consider the additional penalty.Â  However, the court held in the written 
  order that: the additional taxes constituted newly-discovered evidence; the 
  prior evidence regarding the miscalculated tax penalty was submitted as a result 
  of mistake, inadvertence, or excusable neglect; and the additional tax penalty 
  was marital debt of which Husband would be solely responsible.Â  The family courtâ€™s 
  consideration of the additional taxes as marital debt and award of them to Husband 
  lowered Wifeâ€™s award of marital debts from 52% to 47%.
Although Wife complains that the family court 
  committed an error of law in granting Husbandâ€™s Rule 60, SCRCP, motion and considering 
  the additional debt, we find no abuse of discretion.Â  The court found that Husbandâ€™s 
  reliance on his accountantâ€™s figures was justified and the miscalculation was 
  the result of mistake or excusable neglect.Â  Further, the consideration and 
  award of the additional debt did not harm the Wife insofar as she was not required 
  to pay any of the additional debt.Â  Accordingly, we find no error with the family 
  courtâ€™s order granting Husbandâ€™s motion and awarding responsibility for the 
  additional debt to Husband.
III. ALIMONY
Wife argues the family 
  court erred in only awarding her $1,200 a month in alimony.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn award of alimony 
  rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed 
  absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 
  S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAlimony is a substitute for the support that 
  is normally incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  McElveen v. McElveen, 
  332 S.C. 583, 599, 506 S.E.2d 1, 9 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The purpose of alimony 
  is to place the supported spouse in the position he or she enjoyed during the 
  marriage.Â  Id.Â  However, alimony should not â€œserve as a disincentive 
  for spouses to improve their employment potential or to dissuade them from providing, 
  to the extent possible, for their own support.â€Â  Id.Â  
Factors to be considered in making 
  an alimony award include:Â  (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional 
  health of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment 
  history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living during 
  the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; 
  (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital 
  and non-marital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital 
  misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; (12) prior support obligations; 
  and (13) other factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  
At the final divorce hearing, Wife submitted 
  a financial declaration showing expenses for herself and the partiesâ€™ grown 
  son of nearly $4,000 a month.Â  Included in the expenses was a monthly payment 
  on a $27,274 second mortgage on Wifeâ€™s new home; payment on a $9,278 line of 
  credit; and payments on two or more credit cards.Â  Also included as an expense 
  was a $375 monthly car payment.Â  Wife only earned $2,300 in monthly wages.Â  
  By contrast, Husbandâ€™s financial declaration indicated he earned nearly $82,000 
  a year.Â  
In the final divorce decree, the family 
  court considered the statutory factors for alimony.Â  In reviewing Wifeâ€™s expenses, 
  the court specifically held that it would not consider her expenses related 
  to servicing debt in calculating alimony and further found that her expenses 
  might be inflated.Â  Reviewing all the factors, the court awarded Wife $1,200 
  in alimony.Â  In the supplemental order, the court refused to increase the alimony, 
  stating Wifeâ€™s monthly expenses â€œappear to be inflated by debt service on additional 
  borrowing, for a second mortgage and credit card expenditures, which appeared 
  to be excessiveâ€ in light of the substantial cash payout given to Wife by Husband.Â  
  The court also noted that Wife â€œis not fiscally responsible and is likely to 
  spend beyond her means, regardless of the size of award she receives from this 
  court.â€Â Â  
The evidence supports the family courtâ€™s award.Â  
  Both parties were working to their potential and neither suffered from ill health.Â  
  Husband earned substantially more than Wife, and the family court found him 
  guilty of adultery.Â  Although Wife had large expenses, the expenses can predominantly 
  be attributed to credit card debt and debt on a second mortgage.Â  Wifeâ€™s past 
  spending habits is evidence of her lack of fiscal responsibility.Â  Considering 
  these factors, we find the $1,200 a month alimony award is appropriate.
IV. ATTORNEYâ€™S FEES
Wife argues the family court erred in 
  only awarding her $2,570 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
The family court may order payment of 
  attorneyâ€™s fees to a party pursuant to South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(H) 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  Whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees is a matter within the sound 
  discretion of the trial court, and the award will not be reversed on appeal 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 633-34, 
  576 S.E.2d 156, 167 (2003).Â  The family court should consider: the partiesâ€™ 
  ability to pay their own fee; the beneficial results obtained by counsel; the 
  financial conditions of the parties; and the effect of the fee on each partiesâ€™ 
  standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 
  812, 816 (1992).Â  To determine the amount of an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the 
  court should consider: the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; 
  the time necessarily devoted to the case; counselâ€™s professional standing; the 
  contingency of compensation; the beneficial results obtained; and the customary 
  legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 
  161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).
Wife consulted several attorneys immediately 
  following the partiesâ€™ separation. Â She paid fees for representation during 
  the consent agreements totaling nearly $5,000.Â  Wife testified that she charged 
  $2,000 of these fees to her credit card, and the debt was distributed by the 
  court as marital debt.Â  She also incurred $990 in private investigator fees.Â  
  After filing the underlying action for divorce, Wife paid her current counsel 
  $1,500 as a retainer fee.Â  Wifeâ€™s counsel submitted an affidavit for attorneyâ€™s 
  fees to the family court showing that the retainer fee had been spent and Wife 
  owed an additional $2,540.75.Â  Wife requested the family court to award her 
  $11,560 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  After considering the Glasscock factors, 
  the court awarded her $2,570 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â Â  
The amount of fees awarded to Wife is 
  supported by the record.Â  Although Wife spent several thousands of dollars in 
  fees prior to the filing of the divorce action, the record shows she merely 
  consulted some attorneys and the other attorneys only represented her in consent 
  agreements.Â  Further, the $2,000 in credit card debt Wife used to pay legal 
  expenses was counted as marital debt and equitably distributed.Â  The family 
  court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Wife the amount of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees that remained due to her final attorney.Â  
CONCLUSION
The family court correctly held that Husbandâ€™s 
  Corvette was nonmarital property.Â  The evidence supports the family courtâ€™s 
  findings that Wife was guilty of economic misconduct that led to the dissolution 
  of the marriage.Â  The overall distribution of the marital assets was fair, and 
  the court did not abuse its discretion in granting Husbandâ€™s Rule 60, SCRCP, 
  motion to consider and distribute the additional tax penalty.Â  Finally, we find 
  no error with the courtâ€™s award of alimony or attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, 
  the order of the family court is
 AFFIRMED. 
  STILWELL, and SHORT, J.J., concur.

    is not dated.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ernest Steele,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Stephen Benjamin, Director of Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon 
        Services,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3892
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  November 22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ernest Steele, of Bennettsville, pro se for Appellant.
John Benjamin Aplin, and Tommy Evans, Jr., South Carolina 
  Department of Probation, Parole, and Pardon, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Ernest Steele appeals the circuit 
  courtâ€™s denial of his petition for a writ of mandamus against Stephen Benjamin, 
  Director of the South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Services 
  (the Department).Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Steele was convicted of murder in 1967 
  and sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  At the time of his conviction, the law 
  provided that a person was entitled to review for parole after serving one-third 
  of his sentence.Â  See 1962 Code Â§ 55-611 (Supp. 1966) (noting that the 
  Parole Board may parole a prisoner serving a thirty year to life sentence if 
  he has served at least ten years); 1962 Code Â§ 55-611.1 (1962) (providing that 
  a prisoner is entitled to review for parole after he has served one-third of 
  his sentence).Â  The law did not specify how often an inmate who was denied parole 
  would receive review thereafter.Â  
Steele was paroled in 1978.Â  Steeleâ€™s parole was 
  revoked in May 1987 for convictions in Tennessee for Possession with Intent 
  to Resell drugs and driving under the influence. 
  [2] Â  Steele was again granted parole one year later in July 1988.Â  Steele 
  violated his parole and it was revoked on February 9, 1994, due to another conviction 
  for Possession with Intent to Resell Heroin.Â  Steele was denied parole when 
  he next appeared before the Parole Board on May 24, 2000.Â  He was informed that 
  his next review by the Parole Board would be two years later, on August 12, 
  2002.Â  
Steele filed an action in circuit court 
  for a writ of mandamus on December 4, 2000.Â  Steele alleged that he was eligible 
  for annual parole review when he first became eligible for parole and that application 
  of the statutorily required two-year review enacted in 1986 constituted an impermissible 
  ex post facto application of law.Â  He requested the circuit court mandate the 
  Department to apply the annual review in place at the time of his first parole.Â  
  The Department moved to dismiss the action, or, alternatively, for summary judgment.Â  
  The Department argued: (1) Steele had not met the requirements to acquire a 
  writ of mandamus; (2) he was only entitled to parole review every two years; 
  and (3) no ex post facto violation had occurred.Â  
A hearing was held in the matter on February 
  27, 2003.Â  After Steele submitted Erwin v. State, Op. No. 93-MO-286 (S.C.S.Ct. 
  filed Aug. 20, 1993), [3]  the 
  circuit court requested the Department to consider whether granting Steele annual 
  parole review would be a viable option.Â  In a letter, the Department noted that 
  Erwin was a memorandum opinion.Â  The Department informed the circuit 
  court that: (1) Erwin had no precedential value; (2) because no law existed 
  at the time of Steeleâ€™s conviction regarding the timing of parole review after 
  a denial of parole, the Departmentâ€™s internal policy of review every two years 
  controlled; (3) Steele failed to exhaust his administrative remedies when he 
  failed to seek review of the Parole Boardâ€™s decision through the Administrative 
  Law Judge Division (ALJD); and (4) if the Department allowed Steele annual review, 
  it would also have to allow annual review to the 3,000 other inmates similarly 
  situated, which would strain an â€œalready diminishing budget.â€Â  In support of 
  its position, the Department attached to its letter an undated, untitled copy 
  of a document, stating the document was a copy of the Departmentâ€™s parole investigation 
  policies at the time of Steeleâ€™s conviction.Â  The document stated that inmates 
  serving a thirty-year sentence or greater who were denied parole would have 
  a subsequent review for parole after twenty-four months.Â  
After a subsequent hearing in the matter 
  was held on June 2, 2003, the circuit court issued an order denying Steeleâ€™s 
  request for mandamus. [4] Â  The court found that in allowing Steele parole 
  review every two years instead of every year, the Department was applying the 
  â€œlaw/rule/regulation in effect at the time Mr. Steele was sentenced.â€Â  Thus, 
  the court found no violation of the ex post facto clause.Â  The court did not 
  address whether Steele should have exhausted administrative remedies.Â  Steele 
  appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhether to issue a writ of mandamus lies within 
  the sound discretion of the trial court, and an appellate court will not overturn 
  that decision unless the trial court abuses its discretion.â€Â  Charleston 
  County Sch. Dist. v. Charleston County Election Commâ€™n, 336 S.C. 174, 179, 
  519 S.E.2d 567, 570 (1999).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion arises where the trial 
  judge was controlled by an error of law or where his order is based on factual 
  conclusions that are without evidentiary support.â€Â  Tri-County Ice & 
  Fuel Co. v. Palmetto Ice Co., 303 S.C. 237, 242, 399 S.E.2d 779, 782 (1990).Â  
  An appellate court will not disturb the factual findings of the trial court 
  on a mandamus petition if the trial courtâ€™s findings are supported by any reasonable 
  evidence.Â  Charleston County Sch. Dist. at 179-180, 519 S.E.2d at 570. 

LAW/ANALYSIS
The Department points out that Steele 
  failed to exhaust his administrative remedies, and thus, Steele did not meet 
  all the requirements for a writ of mandamus. 
  [5] Â  Steele, however, argues the circuit court had jurisdiction over the 
  mandamus proceedings.Â  Thus, as an initial matter, we address whether the ALJD 
  had jurisdiction to hear Steeleâ€™s claim that the Department violated the ex 
  post facto clause when it denied him annual review of parole eligibility.Â  
The question of whether an inmate may 
  seek review of the Departmentâ€™s and the Department of Correctionâ€™s final decisions 
  under the South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) was answered by 
  our supreme court in Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 527 S.E.2d 742 
  (2000).Â  The court held:

[A]n inmate may seek review of Departmentâ€™s final decision 
  in an administrative matter under the APA.Â  Placing review of these cases within 
  the ambit of the APA will ensure that an inmate receives due process, which 
  consists of notice, a hearing, and judicial review.Â  It also will provide an 
  orderly and consistent framework for resolving such matters.Â  

Al-Shabazz, 338 S.C. at 369, 527 S.E.2d at 
  750.Â  The court emphasized that not all APA provisions apply to the internal 
  prison disciplinary or decision-making process: â€œâ€˜The requirements of procedural 
  due process apply only to the deprivation of interests encompassed by the Fourteenth 
  Amendmentâ€™s protection of liberty and property.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Bd. 
  of Regents of State Colleges v. Roth, 408 U.S. 564, 569 (1972)).Â  The court 
  also said that review of non-collateral or administrative matters, although 
  limited in scope, must be provided in some form, and the APA is the most obvious 
  and practical solution.Â  Id. at 373, 527 S.E.2d at 752.Â  
Ex post facto claims are non-collateral 
  matters.Â  Jernigan v. State, 340 S.C. 256, 260, 531 S.E.2d 507, 509 (2000).Â  
  In Jernigan, the appellant, like Steele, argued that the change from 
  annual parole eligibility review to biannual review violated the ex post facto 
  clause of the federal and state constitutions.Â  Jernigan brought his claim in 
  a PCR application in the circuit court. Â Our supreme court held that Jerniganâ€™s 
  ex post facto claim was non-collateral and had not received an APA review.Â  
  The court held:Â  â€œAccordingly, as a non-collateral matter, petitionerâ€™s claim 
  should be remanded to the appropriate agency to allow it to make a final decision 
  on petitionerâ€™s claim.â€Â  Id.Â  
In Sullivan v. South Carolina Department 
  of Corrections, 355 S.C. 437, 586 S.E.2d 124 (2003), our supreme court held 
  that the only way that an ALJD can obtain subject matter jurisdiction is that 
  the claim must implicate a state created â€œliberty interest sufficient to trigger 
  procedural due process guarantees.â€Â  Sullivan, 355 S.C. at 443, 586 S.E.2d 
  at 127 (citing Wolff v. McDonnell, 418 U.S. 539, 557 (1972); Furtick 
  v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Probation, Parole, & Pardon Servs., 352 S.C. 594, 598, 
  576 S.E.2d 146, 149 (2003); and Al-Shabazz, 338 S.C. at 382, 527 S.E.2d 
  at 757)).Â  Sullivan seems to imply that a quantitative analysis of the 
  liberty interest must be conducted.Â  
The requirement of a liberty interest 
  as pronounced in Sullivan is not new.Â  It was recognized in Al-Shabazz, 
  postulated in Jernigan (citing Al-Shabazz), and directly addressed 
  in Furtick.Â  However, the quantification of the liberty interest was 
  central in Sullivan, yet, like some constitutional issues, it remained 
  nebulous.Â  Sullivan cited Furtick as an example of a sufficient 
  liberty interest required to seek due process in the ALJD.Â  Furtick found 
  â€œthe permanent denial of parole eligibility implicates a liberty 
  interest sufficient to require at least minimal due process.â€Â  Furtick, 
  352 S.C. at 598, 576 S.E.2d at 149.Â  
The use of the word permanent in 
  Sullivan and Furtick does not mean that there must be a permanent 
  denial of parole eligibility before a sufficient liberty interest is involved.Â  
  It is merely one of the ways that a sufficient liberty interest may be involved.Â  
  We must be mindful of the facts in Furtick.Â  Furtick actually had been 
  permanently denied parole eligibility.Â  Sullivan recognizes that Furtick 
  established that an inmate has a right to a ALJD review of an agencyâ€™s final 
  decision denying parole eligibility, but an inmate does not have a right to 
  a review of a denial of parole.Â  The distinction is that the review or consideration 
  for parole is a right granted by statute whereas parole is only a privilege.Â  

In the present case, Steele is not appealing 
  the denial of parole; he is appealing the Parole Boardâ€™s change in the time 
  frame in which it will review parole.Â  The question then becomes whether Steeleâ€™s 
  claim raises a sufficient liberty interest to trigger due process requirements.Â  
  Jernigan is factually similar to the present case.Â  Jernigan, like Steele, 
  alleged that the change from annual parole eligibility review to biannual review 
  violated the ex post facto clause.Â  The Jernigan court held that the 
  change from annual parole eligibility review to biannual review produces a sufficient 
  risk of prolonging incarceration by one year and increasing the measure of punishment 
  attached to the covered crimes.Â  It is axiomatic that any period of incarceration 
  implicates a sufficient liberty interest to trigger due process requirements.Â  

Accordingly, Steeleâ€™s claim was appropriate 
  for disposition under the APA and should have been reviewed by the ALJD.Â  Because 
  he failed to exhaust his administrative remedies, Steeleâ€™s petition for a writ 
  of mandamus was appropriately denied.Â  
CONCLUSION
Steeleâ€™s complaint that the Departmentâ€™s application 
  of biannual parole review to him constituted an ex post facto violation, potentially 
  lengthening the period of his incarceration by one year, implicated a liberty 
  interest.Â  Thus, Steele should have exhausted his administrative remedies by 
  bringing this action pursuant to the APA.Â  Because he failed to pursue this 
  matter through administrative means, his petition for a writ of mandamus was 
  appropriately dismissed.
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of this 
  action is 
 AFFIRMED. 
  [6]   
 STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.Â  

 
   
    [2] Â  In its brief, the Department alleges that Steeleâ€™s parole was revoked 
    in 1985.Â  However, a verification of Steeleâ€™s case history is included in 
    the record.Â  In that document, the Department of Corrections verified that 
    Steele re-entered the Department of Corrections in 1987.Â Â  

 
   
    [3] Â  In Erwin v. State, Op. No. 93-MO-286 (S.C.S.Ct. filed Aug. 
    20, 1993), the appellant pled guilty in 1960, and the Department attempted 
    to apply to him the biannual parole review from S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-645 
    (Supp. 1989).Â  The court held the PCR court erred in finding that Erwin was 
    not suffering an ex post facto violation from the application of the biannual 
    review law enacted decades after his guilty plea.Â  Erwin, at 2.Â Â Â  
  

 
   [4] Â  The record does not contain a transcript of either 
    the February 27, 2003 or the June 2, 2003 hearings.Â  

 
   [5] Â  Although the circuit court did not address whether 
    Steele failed to exhaust his administrative remedies, the Department, as the 
    respondent in this matter, points to other sustaining grounds found in the 
    record.Â  Iâ€™on, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 
    526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000).

 
   
    [6] Â  Because we decide this issue on the additional sustaining ground 
    that Steele failed to exhaust his administrative remedies, we decline to address 
    Steeleâ€™s ex post facto claim.Â  See Iâ€™on, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 
    338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (â€œThe appellate court may review 
    respondentâ€™s additional reasons and, if convinced it is proper and fair to 
    do so, rely on them or any other reason appearing in the record to affirm 
    the lower courtâ€™s judgment.â€); Rule 220 (c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may 
    affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the 
    Record on Appeal.â€).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Carolyn Songer Austin,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Board of Zoning Appeals, Town of Hilton Head Island, South Carolina;
W.J. Enterprises, Inc.; H.D.S. Builders, L.L.C.; Barbara M. Loebig, and 
        National Bank of Commerce,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Master in Equity 
  and Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3893
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 
  22, 2004

 AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Mark Weston Hardee of Columbia, Matthew A. Gess of Beaufort, 
  and Robert E. Austin, Jr., of Leesburg, Florida, for Appellant.
Drew A. Laughlin and Gregory Milam Alford, both of 
  Hilton Head Island, for Respondents.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This is an appeal from a 
  decision of the Town of Hilton Head Island to grant a building permit.Â  The 
  Townâ€™s Board of Zoning Appeals upheld the issuance of the permit, and, on appeal, 
  the circuit court affirmed the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  We also affirm.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In September 2002, the Town of Hilton 
  Head Island issued a building permit for the construction of a single-family 
  home on Lot 18 at the corner of Dune Lane and Jacana Street within the Townâ€™s 
  corporate limits.Â  The permit was approved for a structure that was set back 
  twenty feet from Dune Lane and ten feet from Jacana Street.Â  Carolyn Songer 
  Austin, a neighboring property owner, believed the ten-foot setback on the Jacana 
  Street side of Lot 18 was improper, and that the new home should be set back 
  at least twenty feet from Jacana Street.Â  She subsequently filed an application 
  with the Townâ€™s Board of Zoning Appeals seeking rescission of that permit. 
As part of the permitting process, the 
  Town must ensure the proposed home site is designed with the appropriate setback 
  distances from the street and neighboring property.Â  These setback requirements 
  are designed to preserve the aesthetic character of the surrounding neighborhood.Â  
  As a general rule, the Townâ€™s Land Management Ordinance provides that single-family 
  homes must be set back at least twenty feet from the street, but notes:

For all corner lots, the 20 ft. 
  adjacent street setback may be reduced to 10 ft. on the side of the residence.Â  
  The 20 ft. adjacent street setback shall apply to the street having the highest 
  number of average daily vehicle traffic (ADT) as determined by the Administrator.Â  
  If both streets have equal ADT, the property owner may choose which street to 
  apply the 20 ft. adjacent street setback.Â  

In this case, it was determined there was no evidence that 
  either Dune Lane or Jacana Street had higher average daily traffic, so the decision 
  as to which street to apply the ten-foot setback was left to the property owner.Â  

Austin disagreed.Â  She claimed Jacana Streetâ€”not 
  Dune Laneâ€”had more daily vehicle traffic, thereby requiring the new home on 
  Lot 18 be set back twenty feet from Jacana Street rather than Dune Lane.Â  The 
  Townâ€™s Planning Department examined the matter and determined â€œ[t]here is no 
  evidence that indicates that Jacana Street has a higher traffic volume than 
  Dune Lane,â€ and therefore concluded â€œthe application of a ten-foot setback to 
  [the Jacana Street] side of the property is correct.â€Â  After conducting a hearing, 
  the Board accepted the Planning Department determination and informed Austin 
  by letter that her request to rescind the building permit had been denied. 
Austin appealed the Boardâ€™s decision to the circuit 
  court.Â  Several months after filing her petition, Austin filed two motions with 
  the circuit court that are relevant to the present appeal: first, she filed 
  a motion to amend her petition to add two new grounds; and, second, she moved 
  to supplement the record on appeal to include an additional plat depicting Lot 
  18 and the surrounding property.Â  The circuit court denied both of these motions 
  and ultimately affirmed the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD 
  OF REVIEW
On appeal, we apply the 
  same standard of review as the circuit court below: the findings of fact by 
  the Board shall be treated in the same manner as findings of fact by a jury, 
  and the court may not take additional evidence.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-840(A) 
  (Supp. 2003); see also Heilker v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals for 
  City of Beaufort, 346 S.C. 401, 405, 552 S.E.2d 42, 44 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
  In reviewing the questions presented by the appeal, the court shall determine 
  only whether the decision of the Board is correct as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  
  Furthermore, â€œ[a] court will refrain from substituting its judgment for that 
  of the reviewing body, even if it disagrees with the decision.â€ Restaurant 
  Row Assocs. v. Horry County, 335 S.C. 209, 216, 516 S.E.2d 442, 446 
  (1999).Â  â€œHowever, a decision of a municipal zoning board will be overturned 
  if it is arbitrary, capricious, has no reasonable relation to a lawful purpose, 
  or if the board has abused its discretion.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Austin raises 
  five issues on appeal: She claims (1) the Board failed to set out its final 
  decision in writing as required by statute; (2) the circuit court applied the 
  wrong standard of review; (3) the circuit court improperly denied the motion 
  to amend the petition for appeal; (4) the circuit court improperly denied the 
  motion to supplement the record on appeal; and (5) the Board lacked subject 
  matter jurisdiction to issue its decision.Â  
1.Â  The Boardâ€™s Final Decision
Austin first argues the circuit court 
  erred in finding the Boardâ€™s decision to deny her application was properly issued 
  in writing as required by statute.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina Code section 6-29-800 requires 
  that â€œ[a]ll final decisions and orders of the board must be in writingâ€ and 
  that â€œ[a]ll findings of fact and conclusions of law must be separately stated 
  . . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-800(F) (Supp. 2003).Â  In the present case, the 
  Board informed Austin of its decision by letter dated December 9, 2002, from 
  the Townâ€™s Deputy Planning Director, David L. Recor.Â  In relevant part, the 
  letter advised Austin:

Pursuant to testimony in this 
  matter, the Board of Zoning Appeals concluded and made the following written 
  findings:
  
  1.     
  There is no evidence that indicates that Jacana Street has a higher traffic 
  volume than Dune Lane and therefore it was correct for the Department of Building 
  and Fire Codes to issue a building permit with a ten (10) foot setback on the 
  Jacana Street side of the affected property.
  
The vote on the motion to uphold 
  the administrative determination was 5-1 and therefore the appeal request was 
  denied.

Austin contends this letter does not satisfy the 
  statutory requirement that the Boardâ€™s decision be in writing with findings 
  of fact and conclusions of law separately stated.Â  We find no reversible error.Â  
  Though the statute does not specify the form the writing must take, it is well-settled 
  that courts reviewing the decisions of zoning boards and other administrative 
  agencies may look to written documents as well as records of proceedings as 
  sufficient formats for final decisions.Â  For example, in Vulcan Materials 
  Co. v. Greenville County Board of Zoning Appeals, 342 S.C. 480, 536 S.E.2d 
  892 (Ct. App. 2000), this court upheld a circuit court finding that a transcript 
  of a zoning board hearing constituted a sufficient final written decision.Â  
  On the question of whether the transcript alone could satisfy the statutory 
  requirement of a written decision, the court opined that â€œ[g]enerally, the format 
  of a final decision is immaterial as long as the substance of the decision is 
  sufficiently detailed so as to allow a reviewing court to determine if the decision 
  is supported by the facts of the case.â€ Id. at 494, 536 S.E.2d at 899; 
  cf. Massey v. City of Greenville Bd. of Zoning Adjustments, 341 
  S.C. 193, 201, 532 S.E.2d 885, 889 (Ct. App. 2000) (considering use of transcript 
  but rejecting in part because it was virtually indecipherable). 
In the present case, the evidence considered by 
  the Board is clearly laid out in the transcript of the hearing.Â  Reading this 
  transcript together with the December 9, 2002, letter, therefore, provides sufficient 
  basis for a reviewing court to determine whether the decision was supported 
  by the facts of the case.Â  
Our decision today, however, should not be interpreted 
  as an indication that state and municipal agencies need not follow the mandate 
  of section 6-29-800 and other statutory provisions requiring fully formed written 
  final decisions.Â  In the present case, the issue raised by Austin to the Board 
  was limited to the narrow factual question of determining which of the two streets 
  had a higher average traffic volume.Â  While an exhaustive written decision may 
  not be warranted when a narrow issue may be addressed succinctly by the Board, 
  further detail will surely be required in more complicated cases.Â  Indeed, thorough 
  written findings and determinations eliminate potential confusion and ensure 
  the will of the Board is accurately transmitted to the affected parties and 
  reviewing courts.
2.Â  Standard of Review
Austin next argues the circuit court applied 
  the wrong standard of review.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina Code section 6-29-840 prescribes 
  the standard of review a circuit court should apply when considering an appeal 
  from a local zoning board.Â  In pertinent part, the statute provides: â€œThe findings 
  of fact by the board of appeals must be treated in the same manner as a finding 
  of fact by a jury, and the court may not take additional evidence.â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 6-29-840 (Supp. 2003).Â  It is well-settled that â€œthe factual findings 
  of the jury will not be disturbed unless a review of the record discloses that 
  there is no evidence which reasonably supports the juryâ€™s findings.â€ 
  Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 309 S.C. 237, 240, 421 S.E.2d 402, 404 
  (1992) (emphasis added) (citing Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 
  266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976)).Â  In the present case, the circuit court 
  articulated the standard of review in different terms, stating: â€œFactual findings 
  of the zoning board of adjustment must be affirmed by the circuit court if there 
  is any evidence to support them and if they are not influenced 
  by an error of law.â€ (emphasis added). 
This variance in language is likely the 
  result of confusion that arose after the Legislature enacted an entirely new 
  statutory scheme for local planning and zoning in 1994 in which the standard 
  of review as set out under section 6-29-840 was adopted. 
  [1] Â  Prior to the enactment of the new statute, the standard of review 
  was phrased as an â€œany evidenceâ€ standardâ€”identical to that articulated by the 
  circuit court in the present case.Â  As quoted above, the current statute clearly 
  phrases the proper standard of review as a â€œno evidenceâ€ standard.Â  Austin argues 
  the failure of the circuit court to couch the standard of review in the precise 
  language of section 6-29-840 is a fatal error requiring reversal.Â  This argument 
  is without merit.
We discern no material difference between 
  the standard of review articulated by the circuit court and the standard prescribed 
  by section 6-29-840.Â  Looking carefully at the way the sentences are phrased 
  in the court order and the statute reveals that the distinction between them, 
  if any, is purely linguistic.Â  The circuit court phrases the standard positively: 
  The â€œfindings . . .Â  must be affirmed . . . if there 
  is any evidence to support them.â€ (emphasis added).Â  On the other hand, 
  section 6-29-840, by reference to the common law standard for reviewing a juryâ€™s 
  findings of fact, adopts a standard of review generally phrased in the negative: 
  The â€œfindings . . . will not be disturbed unless 
  a review of the record discloses that there is no evidence which reasonably 
  supportsâ€ them. (emphasis added).Â  When these sentences are read as a whole, 
  therefore, it is clear there is no meaningful difference in the quantum of proof 
  required under the standard formulated by the circuit court and the standard 
  prescribed under the statute.
We have confronted this issue before in 
  Vulcan Materials Co. v. Greenville County Board of Zoning Appeals, 342 
  S.C. 480, 536 S.E.2d 892 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In that case as in the present one, 
  the court was asked to determine whether the circuit court applied the correct 
  standard of review for an appeal of a zoning board decision when the lower court 
  set out the standard using the â€œany evidenceâ€ language rather than the â€œno evidenceâ€ 
  language.Â  After detailing the history of the enactment of the new statute and 
  the confusion it has caused regarding the proper standard of review, the court 
  reached the same conclusion we do today:

We have repeatedly held that 
  the old statute, Â§ 6-7-780, imposed an â€œany evidenceâ€ standard of review . . 
  . .Â  The new statute, Â§ 6-29-840, is also very deferential to a boardâ€™s findings 
  of fact as it equates them to a juryâ€™s findings. . . .Â  The distinction, if 
  any, between an â€œany evidenceâ€ and a â€œno evidenceâ€ standard is of little importance 
  to the instant action . . . .

Id. at 488, 536 S.E.2d at 896.
We therefore find the standards of review 
  set out by the circuit court and prescribed under section 6-29-840 are functionally 
  equivalent.Â  Austinâ€™s argument to the contrary is unpersuasive.
3.Â  Motion to Amend 
Austin next argues the circuit court erred 
  in denying her motion to amend the petition to state additional grounds for 
  her appeal.Â  We disagree.
The procedures governing appeals of Board 
  decisions to the circuit court are prescribed by statute.Â  Section 6-29-820 
  requires that the aggrieved party must file a written petition with the clerk 
  of court â€œsetting forth plainly, fully, and distinctly why the decision is contrary 
  to law.â€Â  Furthermore, this petition â€œmust be filed within thirty days after 
  the decision of the board is mailed.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-820 (Supp. 2003).Â  
  The statute makes no provision for amendment of the grounds set forth in the 
  petition.
Austin, however, argues the circuit court 
  should have freely allowed amendments to the petition.Â  Analogizing to the lenient 
  notice pleading regime of our Rules of Civil Procedure, Austin asserts that 
  parties should have the same latitude to amend petitions appealing a Board decision 
  as they would when seeking to amend any pleading in a civil trial court.Â  This 
  argument misapprehends the function of the circuit court in this case.Â  When 
  reviewing a Board decision, the circuit court sits as an appellate court.Â  Its 
  review is strictly limited to the facts and arguments raised to the Board below.Â  
  Indeed, the circuit court is expressly forbidden from considering any new facts. 
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-840(A) (providing the circuit court â€œmay not 
  take additional evidenceâ€).Â  This is a stark contrast to the circuit courtâ€™s 
  role in its original jurisdiction as a fact finder.Â  There, the Rules of Civil 
  Procedure recognize the reality of the pre-trial and trial process that facts 
  uncovered during the course of ongoing discovery and presentation of evidence 
  necessitate that amendments to initial pleadings be freely allowed in order 
  to conform to newly garnered facts.Â  See, e.g., Rule 15, SCRCP 
  (providing that leave to amend pleadings â€œshall be freely given when justice 
  so requires and does not prejudice any other partyâ€).Â  Therefore, it would be 
  error for the circuit court to adhere to the rules designed to govern the conduct 
  of civil trial litigation when sitting in its appellate capacity.
Our supreme court reached a similar conclusion 
  in Smith v. South Carolina Department of Social Services, 284 S.C. 469, 
  327 S.E.2d 348 (1985).Â  In that case, the appellant filed a petition in the 
  circuit court for review of a final decision issued in a contested case before 
  DSS.Â  As in the present case, the procedure for seeking judicial review of the 
  DSS decision was governed by statute mandating the petition for appeal be filed 
  within 30 days of the Departmentâ€™s decision. Id. at 471, 327 S.E.2d at 
  349.Â  The circuit court dismissed the appeal because the petition failed to 
  specify an error, and it refused to consider the appellantâ€™s motion to amend 
  the petition after the thirty day filing period had expired. Id.Â  In 
  upholding the circuit courtâ€™s decision, the supreme court rejected the appellantâ€™s 
  argument that her motion to amend should have been freely granted, opining: 
  â€œThe appellant contends that the circuit judge erred in failing to consider 
  her Motion to Amend. She relies on the policy of liberally allowing amendments 
  to pleadings. We disagree. This policy does not apply to amendments made after 
  expiration of the thirty-day statutory period for filing the appeal.â€ Id.
Accordingly, we find the circuit court 
  correctly refused Austinâ€™s request to amend the petition after the expiration 
  of 30-day period for filing the appeal.
4.Â  Motion to Supplement the Record
Austin next argues the circuit court erred 
  by denying her motion to supplement the record with an additional plat.Â  We 
  disagree.
As noted in the discussion above, the 
  scope of review for a circuit court reviewing the decision of the Board is strictly 
  proscribed by statute.Â  Section 6-29-840 states:

The findings of fact by the board 
  of appeals must be treated in the same manner as a finding of fact by a jury, 
  and the court may not take additional evidence. In the event the judge determines 
  that the certified record is insufficient for review, the matter may be remanded 
  to the zoning board of appeals for rehearing.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-840(A) (Supp. 2003).
Austin maintains the plat was admitted into evidence 
  at the hearing before the Board, but that the Board, nevertheless, failed to 
  include the plat in the record on appeal. [2] Â  In support of her argument that 
  the plat was considered by the Board, Austin draws our attention to the transcript 
  of the Board hearing where the plat in question was mentioned.Â  Specifically, 
  a zoning board member asked a member of the Townâ€™s Planning Staff whether she 
  provided the Board a copy of a plat she had just referenced in describing the 
  setback requirements in the area surrounding Lot 18.Â  The staff member replied 
  that the plat had not been given to the Board.Â  After canvassing the entire 
  transcript of the hearing, we cannot discern from this fleeting reference sufficient 
  indication that the additional plat was introduced into the record or that the 
  zoning board relied upon it.Â  Moreover, we are bolstered in this view by the 
  fact that another plat depicting the area surrounding Lot 18 was expressly relied 
  upon by the Board and included in the record on appeal.Â  
The circuit court, therefore, did not abuse its discretion 
  in refusing to supplement the record based solely on the briefest mention of 
  an additional plat during the Board hearing.
5.Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction 
Finally, we address Austinâ€™s argument 
  that the Board was without subject matter jurisdiction to uphold the issuance 
  of the building permit.Â  We find this claim is without merit.
Austin asserts that the Boardâ€™s action 
  upholding the building permit effectively â€œalteredâ€ Jacana Street, an action 
  Austin maintains was in excess of the Boardâ€™s statutorily prescribed authority. 
  [3] Â  This allegation stems from some questions raised at the Board hearing 
  concerning whether the portion of Jacana Street that dead-ends into a pedestrian 
  beach access had been classified as a â€œstreetâ€ or â€œpark.â€Â  Homes built on private 
  property abutting areas set aside as â€œparksâ€ under the Townâ€™s Land Management 
  Ordinance need only be set back a minimum of five feet rather than the ten and 
  twenty feet setback distances applicable for streets.
In this case, the issue of whether the 
  Board â€œclassified,â€ â€œaltered,â€ or otherwise viewed any part of Jacana Street 
  as a park is of no consequence to any issue raised in her appeal.Â  Austin invoked 
  the jurisdiction of the Board to address the narrow question of whether the 
  Town erred in issuing the building permit based on her contention that Jacana 
  Street had a higher average daily traffic volume than Dune Lane.Â  The Boardâ€™s 
  ruling only answered this question and did not in any way touch upon whether 
  a portion of Jacana Street was classified as a park, for the Board authorizedâ€”consistent 
  with the applicationâ€”a ten-foot setback along Jacana Street, not a five-foot 
  setback. [4]   
This issue, and the confusion from which 
  it arises, illustrates the Legislatureâ€™s wisdom in requiring that boards of 
  zoning appeals reduce their findings and conclusions to writing.Â  Had the Board 
  in this case prepared a detailed order or memorandum outlining its decision, 
  the extent and effect of the Boardâ€™s action would not be called into question. 
  Nevertheless, we find the Boardâ€™s decision to uphold the building permit did 
  not exceed the bounds of its statutory authority.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order of 
  the circuit court upholding the decision of the Board of Zoning Appeals to permit 
  a twenty-foot setback along Dune Lane and a ten-foot setback along Jacana Street 
  is
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., concur.

    Comprehensive Planning and Enabling Act of 1994).Â Â  All local planning programs 
    were required to be in conformity with the Act within five years of its enactment.
